Pete's luncheonette. Jerry and George are sitting at a               table.]

and, and maybe [again some gestures] she'll see me when               she gets there, does this woman intend to spend time with me?

line: Brian Dickson

So, I fly a lot. I like planes. I was on a plane         the other day and I was wondering - are there keys to the plane? Do they         need keys to start the plane? Maybe that's what those delays on the ground         are sometimes. When you're just sitting there at the gate, maybe the pilot's         just up there in the cockpit going <mimics looking for keys> "Oh,         I don't believe this. Oh my god...I did it again." They tell you         it's something mechanical, because they don't want to come on the PA system..."Ladies         and gentlemen, we're going to be delayed here on the ground for a little         while, I uh...Oh God, this is so embarrassing...I - I left the keys to         the plane in my apartment." You see the technicians all running underneath         the plane; you think they're servicing it, but they're actually looking         for the magnet "hide-a-key" under the wing..."maybe he         left it up there somewhere..."
Jerry's apartment in the middle of the night. Jerry         comes out of his room. We hear his thoughts.

I don't want the keys back! No, I'm glad the way things turned         out. I was clingin' to those keys, man! Like a branch on the banks of         a raging river. And now I have let go. And I'm free...to go with the current.         To float. (To Jerry) And I thank you.

Because you see, George, having the keys to Jerry's apartment?         That kept me in a fantasy world. Every time I went over to his house,         it was like I was on vacation. Better food, better view, better TV. And         cleaner? Oh - much cleaner. That became my reality. I ignored the squalor         in my own life because I'm looking at life, you see, through Jerry's eyes.         I was living in twilight, George. Living in the shadows. Well, not recently. I craved. I crave all the time, constant         craving...but I haven't yearned.
Look at you.
Aw, Kramer, don't start...

character: KRAMER (moving back to the othe side of the booth)
line: You're wasting your         life.
I am not! What you call wasting, I call living! I'm living my         life!
O.K., like what? No, tell me! Do you have a job?
No.
You got money?
No.
Do you have a woman?
No.
Do you have any prospects?
No.
You got anything on the horizon?
Uh...no.
Do you have any action at all?
No.
Do you have any conceivable reason for even getting up in the         morning?
I like to get the Daily News!
George, it's time for us to grow up - and be men. Not little         boys.
Why?
I'm goin' to California. You know, I got the bug.
Yeah, I think I got a touch of something, too.
No, the acting bug. Ever since I was in that Woody Allen movie.
"These pretzels are making me thirsty"? That was one         line! You got fired!
I know, I know, but man! I never felt so alive! Now, are you         coming with me?
Uh, no, I'm not.
Alright, suit yourself. But let's keep this between us - we're         key brothers now. <Gets up to leave.>
You're not really gonna go to California, are you?
Up here, I'm already gone. <Kramer exits.>
Anyway, so he gave me his spare keys, now he wants to have my         keys, so I need mine back from you.
Just 'cause you have his keys? Why does he need yours?
I don't know. He said he wants to be my "key brother."
That's ridiculous.
That's Kramer.
I'll give you back your spare keys - but now I want mine back.
What for?
'Cause. I'll give 'em to Jerry.
Jerry? Why?
'Cause he gave me his.
So what?
So, if he has my keys, I should have his.
Well, I don't see why if you have his, he should have yours.
I just said the same thing to you.
What?
What?
Alright, listen, I'll give you your spare keys, but I don't have         them with me. Can I please have mine to give to back to Kramer?

Yeah, O.K. I'll go get 'em. <George begins to leaf through         papers on Elaine's counter.> What are you doing? Would you just put         that down? <Takes the papers away from George.> I gotta get some         new friends.
Did you bring the keys?
Yes, but I still don't feel right about letting you into Kramer's         apartment without his permission.
This could be an emergency!
You never should have taken away his keys!
I tried to give 'em back, he wouldn't take 'em. <Jerry and         George go out into the hallway to Kramer's apartment.>
How'd the Mets do?
They lost.
Kramer?
Hello, boys.
Hello, Newman.
You lookin' for someone?
Don't play coy with me, Newman, I'm not in the mood!
Coy? I'm not being coy.
Is he being coy?
Yeah, coy.
You're being coy. Now where's Kramer, Newman?
Who?
Listen, Tiny. I wanna know where Kramer is and wanna know now!
Alright, go ahead and hit me, Seinfeld. I got witnesses.
Turn around, George.
Sure. <Turns around.>
George?
Now, you better tell me where Kramer is, or are we gonna have         to do this the hard way? <Hits wall with his fist.>
Help! Help!
Where's Kramer?
HELP! <Elaine enters.>
What's going on?
They're gonna beat me up!
No we're not.
We're trying to find out what happened to Kramer.
You wanna know what happened to Kramer? I'll tell you what happened         to Kramer. He was ticked off. About the keys. Yeah, that's right - about         the keys. Thought he got a bad rap.
Bad rap?
Yeah. From you.
Me?
You heard me. So he packed it up and split for the coast. La-La         Land. L.A.
L.A.?

I never should have taken his keys away. But he drove me to it!         I had no choice! He wouldn't take 'em back. Elaine, you saw it, remember?         I said, 'Take the keys back.' He wouldn't do anything. You saw it, didn't         you see it?
Yeah, yeah, I saw it. <mutters under her breath> I mean,         it's complete bullsh*t.
Huh?
What...?
No, what'd you say?
Nothing. I didn't say anything.
Oh, you didn't see it.
Yeah, I saw it. I saw it! I did, I saw it. Yep.
I heard you say something, there.
I didn't say anything.

I'm calling Kramer's mother. <Picks up the phone, dials.>         (To Elaine) I don't know what you said. But it was something. I heard         something. Hello? Hello, Mrs. Kramer? Mrs. Kramer? Could you turn the         music down? Could you turn the music down!
Ask her about Kramer.
She's drunk out of her mind.

character: JERRY (leaving a message on Elaine's machine)
line: Elaine? Are you there?         It's me, I'm locked out of my apartment, I need my spare keys. Where are         you? I'm at the coffee shop.
Hey! You ever been in an accident?

About five years ago. I was going down this very road. Same time         of day, going about the same speed I'm going now...there was a rock in         the road. Couldn't have been more than a pebble. Never really saw it!         Lost control of the bike, went flyin' about a hundred feet - came down         right on my head. Cracked it wide open! Blood and stuff was just splattered         all over the road, there...I broke every bone in my face. Hey, you know,         when they found me, my eyes were hanging out of their sockets? Yeah, they         pronounced me dead at the scene. I was in a coma for...well, they told         me about a year...said I'd be a vegetable for life. Yeah, but I showed         'em. Ever since then I always wear a helmet! <The biker goes into a         turn.> Lean! <Kramer yells.>
Georgie Boy! Way to come through with the keys! Sit         down, I'm buying you dinner.
Look, I gotta tell ya...I been thinkin' about it, I just don't         feel right about letting you into Elaine's apartment.
Don't feel right? What are you talking about?
Well, you know, I shouldn't have let you into Kramer's, now you         want to go into Elaine's...she entrusted me with her spare keys, how can         I just let you in?
What is the big deal?
Just because you have someone's spare keys, it doesn't entitle         you to break into their apartment. That's the reason you took away Kramer's         keys.

First of all, you're not even supposed to have Elaine's keys.         You're supposed to give 'em back to her, so she can give 'em back to me,         because she has mine. So technically, those are my keys.

Yes, well, if you had never taken your keys back from Kramer,         he never would have taken his back from you and given 'em to me, in which         case I wouldn't have had to take mine back from her.
Well, I want those keys. <Tries to grab the keys from George.>
Nope, no can do.
George, give them to me, I want these keys. <They struggle         over the keys.> I don't want to get physical!
Do you wanna fight?
Do you wanna fight?
I'll fight ya! Not the face! Not the face! <The struggle continues.>
And then, the evil ogre took back the magical keys from the handsome         young prince.
Oh no. He didn't take back the keys, no way.
Yes! And then the handsome young prince was cast out into the         cruel, cruel world.
Oh man, what a bummer. That ogre dude's pretty cold, huh?
Oh, he's cold.

Lemme tell you something, Kramer. If that ogre dude pulled         that crap on me <pulls out a knife> - I'D STAB HIM! I'D CUT HIM         IN HALF! I'D GUT HIM LIKE A FISH, MAN! That's what I'd do!
Yeah, yeah...that'd be funny. (To driver) Hey, you can drop me         here!
Hey, what's the rush, man?
Well, you know, I gotta be goin' now.
Hey, Kramer - have you ever killed a man?
What do you think, junior? You think these hands have been soakin'         in Ivory liquid? <mimics choking somebody>

Don't leave, Kramer, stay with us. You know so much about         the world, we need you, please Kramer! (they all start chanting) Please,         Kramer! Please, Kramer! <Scene ends with Kramer trying to escape their         clutches.>

Don't you see? You're just avoiding the middle man. You were gonna         give her her spare keys, so she was gonna give 'em to me. So, all that's         happening is that instead of giving them to her, you're giving them to         me. It's just unfortunate that when she gave you yours, you didn't give         her hers. 'Cause then she would have given 'em to me, because she has         mine. So then I would have never had to ask you for hers, so that I could         get mine.
You're right, how did I miss that? <Begins unlocking the door,         mutters under his breath> Maybe because it's a crock of sh*t.
What's that?
Nothing.
I heard something.
Didn't say anything. (They go into Elaine's apartment.)
So, how long you been drivin' this thing?
Goin' on four years.
Well, nothin's sexier than a woman behind the wheel of a semi.
Nothin'? (They exchange a glance, then laugh.) Listen to you,         you're quite the sweet-talker.
You know, I always wanted to drive the big rigs. I used to watch         those commercials during the reruns of Gomer Pyle.
You want to give it a try?
Really?
Do you know how to double-clutch?
Yeah.
Well, come on! <They trade places and Kramer gets behind the         wheel. Kramer turns out to be really rusty on the ol' double-clutch.>
They were in here, I saw her put 'em in here!
Well, this is great.
Well, what do they look like?
They look like keys, George. They look exactly like keys. (In         disgust) "What do they look like."
Well, they're obviously not here.
Well, they've gotta be here somewhere.
Jerry, unless I pull down on this statuette and a hidden wall         opens up, we have checked every square inch of this apartment!

character: JERRY (looking through some papers on the desk)
line: What is this? "Murphy         Brown"?
What?
By Elaine Benes?
What?
Elaine's writing a "Murphy Brown"?
Lemme see this. (Tries to grab the papers.)
Wait a second! (They fight over the paper.)
Gimme half!
All right, here!
Why didn't she tell us?

Elaine is writing a sitcom...! <Elaine enters         the room behind Jerry and George. Jerry spots her and tosses his half         of the script at George. George throws it back and paper goes flying everywhere.>
You weasels!
What? What?
How dare you!
We hardly read anything!
It was funny!
Who gave you permission to come into my house and just go through         all my things? You thought it was funny?
Well... <picks up some of the pages> From what I saw...
Well, it's just a first draft!
I was locked out of my apartment, I'm just trying to get my keys.
Why did you let him in?! <Shoves George.>
He forced me to!
I did not!
Yes you did!
You! Get out! Get out! Get out!
Elaine, wait! I need my spare keys!
Here! Here's your damn keys, you keep 'em! I don't want 'em anymore!
Good!
And I want my keys back from you!
What, you don't want me to hold your keys?
No, you can't be trusted!
Alright, alright, fine. <Gives the keys to Elaine.>
And I don't want you to hold mine!
Good! I won't!
Good! Don't! Are these my keys?
These aren't my keys!
Whose are these?
I don't know!
I just thought I could write it.
Is that something you want to do?
I don't know. Those writers make a lot of money.

Elaine, let me tell you something about show business. It's hard         work! You don't just write a "Murphy Brown." You gotta watch         the show, study it, get a sense of the characters, how they relate to         each other.
O.K., can I just watch the show? <mutters under her breath>         God, what an asshole.
What did you say?
I didn't say anything.
I heard something. <Looks at the TV> Elaine, Elaine! It's         Kramer! Kramer's on "Murphy Brown"!
Kramer's on "Murphy Brown"!
Look, there he is, he's sittin' at the desk!
Hi, I'm Murphy Brown, you must be my new secretary.
Oh, good morning, Miss Brown.
And you are...?
Oh, I'm uh, Steven Snell.
Snell. Well, hello, Mr. Snell.
Steven.
Steven. Are you familiar with this computer system?
Oh - I'm familiar with it.
Steven Snell? I know people...and I have a very good         feeling about you. <exits.>

Larry Charles and Tom Cherones

Larry David and Jerry Seinfeld
Larry David
Tom Cherones

Jerry Seinfeld, Michael Richards, Jason Alexander, Julia Louis-Dreyfus,         Wayne Knight (as Newman), Bob Balaban (as Russel) Heidi Swedberg (as Susan),         Kevin Page (as Stu), Len Lesser (as Uncle Leo), Steve Eastin (as cop #1),         David Graf (as cop #2), Al FAnn (as judge), Stephen McHattie (as psychiatrist),         Peter Blood (as Jay) and Julie Bloom (as receptionist)        ================================================================
Where the hell did I put this?
What are you looking for?
The remote, the remote, I can't find the remote. Did I lost, I         lost it. Did you take it? Did you put it some place?
No, no, no.
All right, what is this?
what is what?
All right, very funny. I get it.
You're in a weird mood.
Come on. Go back to your apartment and fix it.
Fix what?
Your pants!
what is this? What have I got one pant leg on for?
Don't you know? Look-look at your face! You only shaved the right         side of your face! What is this? A joke?
No, t's a joke.. a joke... a joke... you think this is funny?
Go look at your face in the mirror.
Wha-huh-wha-huh...
yeah?
It's George.
Come on up.
I don't believe this.
You mean, you didn't know you were doing any of these things?
No, I swear.
I bet this is from that kick from that crazy Joe Davola. You better         see a doctor and get some X-rays.
Ah! You're just the man I'm looking for.
Me?
Yeah, here you go.
What's this?
A dry-cleaning bill?
From that woman at NBC?
Yeah.
A dry-cleaning bill for what?
For vomiting on her vest!
Oh, come on George! I didn't do that on purpose!
Well, I shouldn't have to pay for it!
Well, neither should I! Jerry's the one who left the milk in         the refrigerator.
Yeah, your milk.
He drank it.
I didn't know.
All right, well, we should all chip in I guess.
Yeah.
How much was it to clean the vest?
Eighteen dollars.
Can you get vomit out of suede?
I don't know.
Yo-yo Ma!
What? Yo-yo Ma?
What about him?
You just said 'Yo-yo Ma'.
What's Yo-yo Ma?
He's a cellist. (to Kramer) You should see a doctor today.
All right, come on, come on, let's go. Six dollars.
I can't believe she sent you that dry-cleaning bill.
I know!
That doesn't really bode well for the show, does it?
The show! Forget about the show! We should take the idea to a         different network
Oh, yeah. Right. Like anybody's ever gonna do this! How did you         get me to go along with that? A show about nothing!
It was a good idea. Susan liked it. Now, if he hadn't vomitted         all over her, we'd be writing it right now.
Jeez!
Anyway.
What are you doing? What's wrong with you? What're         you doing? Give me that phone! Go to your apartment and lie down, I'll         make an appointment for a doctor today.
What?
NBC! They wanna have another meeting about the idea.
They wanna have another meeting? They wanna buy it?! They wanna         but it?! Oh! I tell you! We're gonna be rich!! What are we gonna get for         this? Fifty, sixty thousand?
I don't know about sixty.
Oh, it's gotta be fifty! Hee hee! You know how much Ted Danson         makes, huh?
Ted Danson! Now, how are you comparing us to Ted Danson?
I didn't say 'We're Ted Danson.'
Yes, you did. You said 'We're Ted Danson'!
Oh!
You know, I think he wears a piece.
Yeah, don't worry. He can afford it.
I'm ten minutes slow again! That's it for this piece of junk!         I've had it.
What, is that the one your parents gave you?
Yeah! But it never works. You know we're supposed to be there         by two o'clock. We should take a cab.
All right, we'll be a little late, I,m not taking a cab.
I'll pay for it.
It's not the money!
Well, what is it you object to? The comfort? The Speed? The convenience?
Jerry!
Uncle Leo!
Helloooo!
Hello there, how're you doing?
Ha ha! How are you?
Good, good.
How's your mom and dad?
Good, fine.
What are you getting to be too much of a big shot now to give me         a call? I don't hear from you anymore!
Oh, no. I've been kinda busy. It's all.
You know where I just came from?
Oh, sure. Danny.
He used to be in the pajama business. I used to be able to get pajamas         for free. I used to come over and get pajamas all the time!
Oh, yeah, yeah. I remember.
I-I'm sorry Uncle Leo, I really gotta get going.
Oh. Well. You gotta get going, so go.
We, we got a big meeting with the president of NBC.
Nobody got a gun to your head!
Yeah, I'm really sorry, uh.
Go. Really. I understand. You got an appointment, go to your appointment.
I'm sorry, really.
You know, I know plenty of people in Hollywood too!
Sorry, really.
Yeah?
Come on, are you ready? Let's go!
For what?
What's the matter with you? I just talked to you fifteen minutes         ago.
what about?
The courthouse. You gotta go with me to the courthouse. I'm contesting         a ticket today.
I can't, I'm going to the doctor's later.
You gotta go with me. I mean, you-you're my alibi. You have to         take the stand.
Well, I can't!

Well, let me remind you of something. You wouldn't be here if         it wasn't for me and my helmet. I saved your life! You would be dead!         Dead! You would cease to exist! You would be gone for the rest of eternity!         You wouldn't even begin to comprehend what that means!!
Shut up! I'll get my coat!

You see the look on my uncle's face? Did you see how insulted         he was? What could I do? Waht are we supposed to do? You can't leave.         There's no excuse good enough to justify walking away from a conversation         with one of my relatives.
I didn't shave this morning. I don't feel like myself.
Look at this.
Why didn't you shave this morning?
'Cause I shaved yesterday in the afternoon.
Why?
Because of the day before. It's a long story.
Is that Joe Davola?
It's not him!
I can't live tlike this. I'm being stalked.
Mister Seinfeld? They're ready for you.
Oh.
Mister Seinfeld? What about Mister Costanza? I'm not here?
All right. Look. Now, you promised you're gonna be a little more         flexible on the nothing idea, okay? Jsut a little.
Okay. A little.
Okay, you're all set? You got your story?
No.
When the cop stopped me, I told him that I was rushing home because         my friend was about to commit suicide.
Uhm...
Now, you're that firend. Now, all we need is a reason why you         were going to commit suicide.
I never had an air conditioner.
No! That's no reason to kill yourself!
Why? It gets hot at night, you can't sleep. You ever tried to         sleep in a really hot room?
Every night I sleep in a really hot room, I don't want to kill         myself.
Well, I slept in really hot rooms and I wanted to kill myself.
No, no, no. That's not gonna work. Something else.
I was never able to become a banker.
Banker! So you're killing yourself because your dreams of becoming         a banker have gone unfulfilled. You-you-you-you can't live without being         a banker.
Yeah, yeah. If I can't be banker, I don't wanna live.
You must be banker.
MUST be banker.
Okay, we'll go with the banker story.
The story is the foundation of all entertainment. You must have         a good story otherwise it's just masturbation.
And people really have to care about the characters.
Care? Forget about care. Love. They have to love the characters.         Otherwise, why would they keep tuning in?
Wouldn't tune in.
Would they tune in?
No tune.
We like to look at the show as if it were in EKG. You have your         highs and your lows and it goes up and down.
The show will be like a heart attack!
Just a huge massive coronary.
So what you said last week about no story, you're a little flexible         on that now.
Is-is that what I said 'no story'? Because Jerry had to tell         me later.
He couldn't believe it.
Well, I informed him that he was exceeding the speed         limit and uh, that's when he told me that he was racing home because his         friend was about to commit suicide.
And then what happened?
Look. I don't know how you two guys feel but we would really         like to be in business with you.
Well, we would like to be in business. Let's do business. We'll         have some business. Let's have business.
We would love to be in business. We'll do business. We're in business.         It's... it's business. This is business.
Yeah!
Would it be possible to get a-a-a copy of 'La Cocina'?
Your off-Broadway play.

Oh, oh. Uh, you know. It's the damndest thing. I, uh, I moved         recently and my files, pfff, disappeared. Now, I-I don't know if they         fell off the truck or if there was some sort of foul play but let me tell         you something. I'm not through with that moving company.
Hmm, hmm.
That's my vow to you.
Well, I got a feeling about you two. And even more than that.         I place a great deal of confidence in that lady's judgment.
Oh! That's good judgment. That's a pile of judgment there. Sure.
Oh! Taht's judgment. Yes, yes. Judgment with earrings on. Yeah.
So, let's make a pilot.

I had gone up to Westchester. I go there every Tuesday. I do         charity for the blind in my spare time for the Lighthouse. I was in the         middle of a game of Parcheesi with an old blind man and I excused myself         to call my friend as he was very depressed lately because he never became         a banker.
I don't understand.

You see, it'd been his lifelong dream to be a banker and he uh,         just the day before he was turned down by another bank. I believe it was         the Manufacturer's Hanover on Lexington and 40th Street. That was the         third bank to turn him down so I was-I was a little concerned. I wanted         to see how he was doing. Well, Your Honor, he was barely audible. But         I distinctly recall him say...
Yo-yo Ma!

So I sped home to save my friend's life and I was stopped for         speeding. Yes, I admit I was speeding but it was to save a man's life.         A close friend. An innocent person who wanted nothing more out of life         than to love, to be loved and to be a banker.
So then he didn't kill himself.
No sir. He did not. But only by thge grace of God. He's in the         courtroom today
See?
Yeah!
I told you, I told you! Ha ha ha! Ooh ooh!
Now, all we gotta do is write it.
Yes! How're we gonna do that?
Hey! Congratulations!
Thanks.
Oh, thank you.
Thank you, thanks.
Thanks. Gee, you know, I thought you were mad at me.
No.
Mister Seinfeld, you have a phone call.
Phone call? Who knows I'm here?
When you sent me the-the bill for the dry-cleaning. I thought         the show didn't have a chance.
Oh, it was only vomit.
Anyway, I-I would like to-to pay for the cleaning.
No-no-no, we all chipped in. We have the money.
Well, it was eighteen dollars.
Okay, uh, eighteen dollars, and there it is. There you go. So         maybe we could get together this weekend.
Yeah. Call me.
All right, great.
Bye.
Bye thanks.
Bye, thanks. (To Jerry, when Susan is far) I can't         believe she took the money.
Why?
I offered to pay. She should've said no.
She did, you insisted.
Maybe this is what the pilot should be about, vomiting on somebody's         vest.
Nah!
How much are we gonna get for this? Fifty, sixty thousand?
oh, I d-I don't know. I d---
Oh, gotta get fifty. Gotta get fifty. All right, I tell you what.         We go to the coffee shop, you call your manager. Maybe they made an offer.
Okay.
All right, let's go, let's go,         let's go, come on.
Thirteen thousand?
Thirteen thousand.
a piece?
No, for both!
That's insulting! Ted Danson makes eight hundred thousand dollars         an episode.
Oh, would you stop with the Ted Danson?
Well, he does.
You're nuts!
I'm sorry. I can't live knowing Ted Danson makes that much more         than me. Who is he?
He's somebody.
What about me?
You're nobody.
Why him? Why not me?
He's good, you're not.
I'm better than him.
You're worse, much much worse. (crouches in booth) That's Davola!
What? Where? Where?
Outside! I saw him outside!
what is it?
Oh, it's this patient.
Again?
I'm fairly certain. I forgot to leave him an extra prescription         for his medication.
Well, so, he can live without his Valium for a couple of days.
Nah, you don't understand. He could be dangerous.
Go outside and see if he's still there.
I can't go out there, he knows we're friends.
Well, what are we supposed to do? I gotta take Kramer to the doctor.
Tell the cop.
Good idea.
Yeah, all right. Just let me get a muffin.
Thanks.
He's gonna get a muffin and then he'll walk us         outside. This is a great way to go through life.
I thought you said he was gonna get a muffin.
What are you doing?
What?
What, are you ordering food now?
Yeah! Yeah, I decided to get a sandwich.
What happened to the muffin?
I got a little hungry.
All of a sudden you get hungry?
Yeah! You got a problem with that?
No! Enjoy your lunch.
He's getting a sandwich now!
I thought he was just gonna have a muffin.
All of a sudden he gets hungry.
You know, a muffin can be very filling.
I know!
Mister Kramer, you heard the testimony         so far. Would you please tell the court in your own words what happened         on the afternoon of September 10th?
What do you mean 'my own words'? Whose words are they gonna be?
You know what I mean.
I was very upset that day.
And why was that?
Would you let me say it? Let me talk!
All right, all right. Go ahead, go ahead.
All right.
Okay.
I was very upset that day because I could never become         a banker.
And that failure to become a banker was eating at you. Eating-eating-eating         at you inside.
Uh, yeah.
It was your family that pushed you into banking , it was their         dream for you...
Mister Newman.
Your Honor, I'm only trying to establish Mister Kramer's fragile         emotional state, my entire case depends on it.
Uh, continue.
As you were saying, Mister Kramer...
What was the question?
You're telling how your parents pushed you into banking.
But you never became a banker, did you Mister Kramer? Why? Why         did you fail?
I don't know.
It was because you hated your father and you would do anything         to displease him. Isn't THAT true?
Uh, could you get to the speeding?
Yuh, yes. I intend to Your Honor. And then, on the afternoon         of September 10th, you received a phone call did you not?
Phone call?
Yes, a phone call!
From who?
From me!
From you?

Oh. (Notices Louis' jacket) Isn't that, uh, your..
(Trying to avoid the issue) Oh, yeah, yeah, Okay, we're               going. (To his three friends) Vamanos, muchachos!
(Turns to George, he is now reading a book) Hey, what are               you reading?
Oh, uh, "The Falconer" by John Cheever. It's               really excellent.
(To Jerry) John Cheever, you ever read any of his stuff?
Uh, yeah, I'm familiar with some of his writing. (George               shoots Jerry a smirk, then returns to his book) Alright, (Hand the               check to Elaine) look, we gotta
(Folding up the check) Ok, I'll leave you two alone.
(Moving back into the living room) Okay.
(In the door way) Maybe I'll go visit my mother. She just               bought me some new panties (Jerry pauses right before sitting in               his chair) and they're - all laid
We're dead.
We're not dead.
We are dead.
Come on. We got all day tomorrow to come up with a story.
All day tomorrow? We had a month and a half to come up with               something and we didn't do anything.
So we'll do it tomorrow.
Let me ask you something. When's the last time you went               skiing?
About six years ago.
I think you can take the lift ticket off your jacket now.
Women like skiers.
So what? You can't meet anybody. You're going on with Susan.
Yeah. Right.
Hey, see those two women over there? I almost dated the               one on the right. She's in the closet business.
The closet business? What's the closet business?
What is it your business?
I'm interested.
She reorganizes your closet and shows you how to maximize               your closet space. She looked into my closet.
So you thought she was good looking and figured this would               be a good way to meet her.
Yeah.
Yeah. So what happened?
So, she mentioned she had a boyfriend and then it hit me.               What do I need more closet space for? (Across the room) Hi, Marla.
(Walks over to Jerry and George) Jerry.
George, Marla.
Marla.
George. Jerry, Stacey.
Stacey.
Jerry.
George, Stacey.
Stacey.
George.
George.
Jerry. Marla. (Realizing Jerry's cue) Stacey! (Walks over               to Stacey)
So, how was your trip to Berlin?
Trip to Berlin?
Remember? That's why you put off doing the closets. You               said you were going to Berlin for a while.
Oh, right, right.
The wall had just come down, and you told me you wanted               to be part of the celebration.
Yes, yes, I did. But, you know, I was watching it on CNN,               and they covered it so well I thought, "Why knock my brains               out?"
You, know my boyfriend went.
Really?
Yes, I told him all about you going and he got all excited               and decided to go.
Oh, did he like it?
I don't know. He never came back. (Over to the other side               of the bar)

Anyway, we met with NBC about a month ago and they gave               us the green light to go ahead and write a pilot. In fact, we got               a big meeting with them tomorrow. They gotta approve of the story               before we can write.
Wow, what a great job. A writer.
Not a bad way to make a buck.
Sounds great.

Well, I'll tell you, Stacey. It's a lot of hard work. But,               it comes fairly easy to me. Some people write symphonies. This is               my gift. (Raises ski lift ticket while Stacey looks away)
So, are you gonna go out with her?
I might.
What about Susan?
What? I'm not married. I'm not allowed to go out with somebody               else?
Depends.
Depends on what?
On many factors.
Like what?
Well, how long you've been seeing her. What's your phone               call frequency? Are you on a daily?
No. Semi-daily. Four or five times a week.
What about Saturday nights? Do you have to ask her out,               or is a date implied?
Implied.
She got anything in your medicine cabinet?
There might be some moisturizer.
Ah hah. Let me ask you this. Is there any tampax in your               house?
(Pause) Yeah.
Well, I'll tell you what you've got here.
What?
You got yourself a girlfriend.
Ah, no, no. Are you sure? A girlfriend?
I'm looking at a guy in a semi-daily with tampax in his               house and an implied date on Saturday night. I would like to help               you out, but...

Would you believe my luck? The first time in my life I               have a good answer to the question, "What do you do?"               and I have a girlfriend. I mean, you don't need a girlfriend when               you can answer that question. That's what you say in order to get               girlfriends. Once you can get a girlfriend, you don't want a girlfriend,               you just want more girlfriends.
You're going to make a good father someday.
Well it's not fair, Jerry. It's just not fair. All right,               all right. That's it. I'm getting out of this thing.
Fine. Break up with her. But you know what this means?
No, what?
The script, the pilot, the TV show. That's all over.
Why? What do you mean?

Figure it out. She's one of the executives at NBC that's               gonna make the decision whether or not they pick up the show. She's               one of our biggest fans. You drop her off, you think they're gonna               pick us up?
Oh, right. Oh no, man.

you know, it's a very interesting situation. Here you have               a job that can get you girls. But, you also have a relationship.               But if you try and get rid of the relationship so you can get the               girls, you lose the job. You see the irony?
Yeah, yeah. I see the irony. All right. What about this?               What if I can find some way to break up with her so that she'll               still like me and it doesn't affect the deal.
(sarcastically) Oh, yeah.

Wait, wait. Here me out. Don't dismiss this. You're very               quick to dismiss. Don't dismiss. She's got a big crush on David               Letterman, I mean, a big crush. She talks about him all the time.               Suppose I go up to David Letterman. He works at NBC; I work at NBC.               I explain my situation. He agrees to meet her. They go out, they               fall madly in love. And she dumps me for David Letterman.
This is your plan?
No, no. I'm just thinking.
I don't think you are.
Let me tell you what I think.
Please, and be brutal. I have no closet sensitivity.
Are you very fussy about your pants?
I don't think I am.
Because I have a very radical idea. Can you handle it?
Try me.
Here's what I'm proposing. We eliminate all this. The hangers,               the bar, the shelves. And in its place install a series of hooks.               We'll put everything on hooks.
Everything?
Everything. The shirts, pants, sport jackets, pajamas. We               could get eighty hooks on here.
You're quite mad, you know. (Kramer enters) Oh, I don't               believe this. (Goes into other room) Hey?
Hey.
What are you doing?
I'm watching The Bold and the Beautiful.
No.
What?
This is not a good time.
Five minutes. What?
What did you have to give your TV away to George for?
Because I've been watching too much. It was an addiction.               I couldn't stop. It was, it was destroying my brain cells.
Yeah, but now you're in here all the time. (Marla enters               from other room)
Well, wow.
Marla, Kramer.
Hey.
Why don't you go out? It's nice out.
Oh, no. There's nothing out there for me.
There's weather.
Weather? I don't need weather. Weather doesn't do it for               me.
I'm tellin' George to give you your TV back.
No, no, I don't want it back. (Pause) Are you gonna watch               the Knick game tonight?
I don't know.
Will you tape it?
Kramer... (points to Marla)
Yeah. (He exits)
So your boyfriend never came back from Berlin.
Never came back.
Oh, you must have been devastated being left for a wall.
It was about to end anyway. There was this... problem.
Ah hah. (Buzzer) Excuse me one second. Yeah?
It's me.
Come on up. Oh, it's Elaine, she's just a friend of mine.               I don't know what she's doing here now. (Buzzer) I'm sorry. What?
I didn't get it.
Ugh. So you were saying there was this problem.
Well, he wanted me to move in with him.
Snapple?
No thanks.
Go on.
Well I wouldn't move in because...
Yes.
Well because...
Yeah.
Well because I'm a virgin. (Elaine enters)
Hello!
Hi, um. Marla, Elaine.
I'm sorry, I didn't know you had company. I just wanted               to return your tape.
Oh, thanks a lot, two weeks late. Now that costs me thirty-five               dollars to see Havana.
I'm sorry, I really am. I just kept forgetting.
I should be going.
No, no, I'm leaving.
I like that thing in your hair there.
Oh yeah? This woman was selling them at this crazy party               I was at last night. You'll appreciate this. Snapple?
No thanks.

I was talking to this guy, you know, and I just happened               to throw my purse on the sofa. And my diaphragm goes flying out.               So I just froze, you know, ahh! Staring at my diaphragm. You know,               it's just lying there. So then, this woman, the one who sold me               this hair thing, she grabbed it before the guy noticed, so. I mean,               big deal, right? So I carry around my diaphragm, who doesn't? Yeah,               like it's a big, big secret that women carry around their diaphragms.               You never know when you're gonna need it, right? (Sips the Snapple)               Ahh.
I should be going.
So we'll talk about the hooks then?
Yes. (She exits)
What? Was it something I said?
She's a virgin, she just told me.
Well I didn't know.
Well it's not like spotting a toupee.
Well you think I should say something? Should I say something?               Should I apologize? Was I being anti-virgin?
No, no, I mean...
'Cause I'm not anti-virgin. I'll be right back. (She leaves)
Elaine, Elaine... (Buzzer) Yeah?
It's George.
She's a virgin?
A virgin.
Wow. So what're you gonna do?
I don't know. I'm very attracted to her. That accent, it's               so sexy.
I don't think I could do it. You know, they always remember               the first time. I don't want to be remembered. I wanna be forgotten.
You need a little pioneer spirit. You know, you don't have               any of that Lewis and Clark in you.
You know, sometimes those guys don't make it back. (Looks               in fridge) I'm really hungry.
Yeah, me too.
We gotta get something. I don't want to go to that meeting               on an empty stomach. Let's get some Chinese. You wanna order it?

All right, but then we gotta get some work done. Let me               just call Kramer, see if want anything. (Calls) Hey, we ordering               Chinese food. If you want anything-- (Kramer enters quickly) let               me know what it is and I'll order for you.
I'm in. Let's go for it.
What do you want?
I don't care, whatever.
I'll tell you what. Why don't we just get a couple of dishes               and we'll just share 'em.
Okay. What are you getting?
I'm gonna get a Chow Fung.
What's a Chow Fung?
It's a broad noodle.
What do you mean, a broad noodle?
It's a big flat noodle.
Well I don't want a big flat noodle.
What kind of noodle do you want?
Who says I want a noodle?
All right, look. I'm getting the Chow Fung. You don't have               to have any.
All right. I'll get pea pods and you can't have any of               my pea pods.
Fine.
Get extra MSG.

Look, Marla. This whole sex thing is totally overrated.               Now, here's the one thing you've gotta be ready for is how the man               changes into a completely different person five seconds after it's               over. I mean, something happens to their personality it's really               quite astounding. It's like they committed a crime and they want               to flee the scene before the police get there.
So they just leave?

Yeah, pretty much, yeah. Well, the smart ones start working               on their getaway stories during dinner. How, you know, they gotta               get up early tomorrow. What is about being up early? They all turn               into farmers suddenly.
Wow. It must be pretty good to put up with all that.
Eh.
All right, let's go. We don't have much time before the               meeting.
Where's the food? What happened to Ping?

Don't worry, he'll be here. Look, we only got about two               hours. We just need to come up with one good story so we can get               through this meeting. (Buzzer) There's your food.
Hey, what about this? I'm in a car accident. The motorist               is uninsured, you with me?
Yeah.
My car's totaled. It's all his fault and now, he has absolutely               no money. There is no way that he can pay me. So the judge decrees               that he becomes my butler.
Your butler?
Right. He cooks my food, he cleans my house, he does all               my shopping for me. And there you go, that's your program.
What about me?
Don't worry, we'll find something for you. (Knock of Jerry's               door)
(Getting the door) That's the stupidest idea I ever heard.               Sentenced to be a butler. (Elaine, Marla, and an injured Ping are               at the door) Ping, what happened?
There was a bit of an accident.
Head hurts. Head really hurts.
What happened?

Marla and I went out for coffee and afterwards I was crossing               the street and he was biking right towards me. So I got out of the               way just in time, but then he ran into a parked car. He hit his               head and everything went flying.
Something happened to the food?
I only saved one bag.
Should I call an ambulance? Do you wanna see a doctor?
I'll get some ice.
(After looking in the bag) The pea pods? All you saved               was the pea pods? (Kramer enters)
Hey, you got the food?
Yeah, here.
What took you so long? Hey, Ping!
Kramer. (Kramer and George sit on the couch)
Yeah. Where's yours?
He dropped it.
Oh, that's too bad.
You should slow down, you know that? It's dangerous to               go that fast.
No, no. I have green light. You jaywalked.
(To Jerry) Hey, you watchin' Oprah?
(To Ping) I did not jaywalk.
(To George) You're givin' him back that TV.
(To Elaine) Yes, you jaywalked.
(To Jerry) No, I don't want it back.
(To Elaine) Jaywalker. I could slap suit on you.
(To Jerry) We got work to do. What about the meeting?
(To himself) Hey, look. An hour with Patrick Swayze.

A month and a half we had. We did nothing. I can't believe               we put it off until today and then we couldn't do anything because               Elaine runs out to apologize to a virgin, crosses against a light,               and knocks over a Chinese delivery boy. Now we're gonna make fools               of ourselves, we got nothing. You're not even in show business.               I gotta reputation. You drag me into the sewer with you. I've been               on TV buddy boy. You know how fast word spreads in show business?               It's like that (Snaps in George's face) , like that! One bad impression,               you're outta the business!
All right, let's postpone it. Let's get out of here.
What do you mean? They know we're here.
I'll fake an illness. (Acts it out) My back! My back! I               can't believe, my back.
No, no, would you get up?
I can do this, Jerry.
No.

All right, I'll tell them my sister died. (Starts fake               crying) My poor sister died. She was standing and then she was laughing               and then they SHOT her! That's the kind of sick city that we're               livin' in. They shoot you for laughing. I must go and comfort my               poor family. Jerry, take me home so I can comfort my... my poor               family.
What?
That's David Letterman. I just saw David Letterman walk               by. I'll be right back. (He exits)
Mr. Seinfeld, they're ready for you. (She exits)
Yes, I was very wise to hitch my wagon to his star. (Jerry               enters meeting)
Hey, Jerry.
Hi, how are you doing? Nice to see you all here. Hello.
Hello, Jerry. I'm Rita Kearson.
Oh, uh, nice to meet you. Where's Russell?
He, uh, had to go to LA. There's a problem on the set of               Blossom.
Oh, poor Blossom. (He sits)
Anyway, he asked me to sit in for him.
Where's George?
Oh, he ran to say something to David Letterman.
David Letterman's on the floor?
Yeah, he just walked by.
Well, I think we should get started anyway.
Yeah, good idea.
So how are you guys comin' along?
Good, good, we've got a lot of ideas.
Good. (Pause)

Have you ever been to a Chinese restaurant and they tell               you it'll be, like, five minutes for a table and you wind up waitin'               there for, like, thirty minutes? Well, we thought it would be very               funny to do an entire show where all you're doin' is waitin' for               the table. (They don't seem to like it) Because we've all been in               that situation. You know, you're waiting... and you're hungry...               and you bump into somebody you know... When is Russell coming back?
So that's the idea?

Well no, that's one. We have many others. We have an idea               where, uh, I get into an accident with a guy who has no insurance               and the judge sentences him to be my butler. (Everyone laughs) You               know he cooks for me, he has to cook for me... He cleans my house,               he's doin' my shopping, you know? I'm walkin' around with one of               those big neck collars.
Those collars are funny!
Once you see someone in those collars you start laughing               immediately. (George enters)
You tellin' 'em about the butler story? Is that beautiful               or what? Hey, sorry I'm late. (Looks at Rita) Russell?
I'm Rita Kearson.

Oh, Rita. Hey, Mr. Shermack, how're you doing, good to               see you. Jay, always a pleasure. (To Susan) Sweetie. (Kisses her               and then sits down next to Jerry) Yeah, yeah, that butler idea,               that's beautiful. Isn't that killer? (Aside to Jerry) I thought               I was getting the butler.
Don't worry, uh, we'll find something for you.
So Letterman didn't spark to your idea, huh?
No, he said there was nothing he could do, and next time               I should probably break the Prozacs in half.
You, you guys wanna hold it down? I'm watchin' Jeopardy.
Would you give him the TV back?
Oh, by the way, George. Susan called for you a minute ago.
I bet they're probably doing summersaults about us over               there. You think they get butler stories like that everyday? (He               calls Susan)
(To the TV) Who is Joseph Cotton? Giddee up!
Hello?
Hi, it's me. It's Georgie Boy. What's going on?
What's going on? What's going on? I'll tell you what's going               on. I'm fired!
Fired? Why?
Because you kissed me. You kissed me, you stupid idiot!               Rita called Russell and he fired me over the phone.
(To the TV) What is pi? Ooh! Giddee up again.
But I had no... I didn't realize.
You didn't realize? How could you not realize? You're stupid!               You're a stupid, stupid man!
I just feel terrible This is just terrible.
(To the TV once again) What is the cha-cha? Ooh, yes indeed.
I'll speak to you later.
(Hangs up phone and pauses) this is great! He fired her!               This is incredible, he fired her. I'm out, baby! I'm out!
Why did he fire her?
Because I kissed her in the meeting. Russell found out,               he fired her over the phone. Finally, my stupidity pays off!
What is here comes the judge, here comes the judge!
You can't break up with her now. Her life is shattered.               You got her fired. You gotta be there for her.
What?
You gotta at least wait until she gets another job.
Another job?
Couple of interviews.
Oh, this is unbelievable. I'm stuck. Every time I think               I'm out, they pull me back in.
Are you gonna leave after its over? You know, if we have               sex.
What? Leave? Where? Why?
You know, the apartment.
Why would I leave? This is my apartment.
Well what if it was my apartment?
Who gave you this idea I would wanna leave?
Well Elaine said men like to leave after it's over.

Listen, I wouldn't put too much stock into what Elaine has               to say about relationships. She comes from a broken home, and I               mean that literally. A tree fell on her roof and cracked the whole               structure. Her parents got along beautifully, but her house was               in bad shape.
Maybe I should get going.
What else did you say to her?
Nothin'. I was just givin' her the straight dope.
More like a dope was giving it to her straight. Another               cup of coffee with you, she'll wind up in a convent.
Listen, there was a lot more I could've told her, believe               me.
What is that about leaving after sex? Did I ever leave with               you?
You might've if I'd stayed. So you know what? I got served               with papers today. Ping is suing me. I need your virgin as a witness.               You better be nice to her.
I was trying to be.
Look at George. (On the other side of the restaurant) He               lucked out, huh?
Oh, you're not kiddin'. Who'd 've figured Susan would break               up with him? They had a good thing going.

Yeah, since she met him she's been vomited on, her family               cabin's been burned down, she learned her father's a homosexual,               and she got fired from a high paying network job. Yeah, they had               a real good thing going.
What do I do? Well actually, I'm a writer. In fact, I'm               writing a comedy pilot for NBC right now.
A sitcom? How can you write that crap? Carol, this guy's               writing a sitcom.
A sitcom? Come on, let's go. (They leave)
A sitcom. Can you imagine? And he actually tried to use               it to hit on me!

line: Larry David
Tom Cherones
November 18, 1992 for the first time.
Jerry Seinfeld, Michael Richards,
Monk's Coffee shop]
(To Elaine) Let me ask you a question.
Mm-hm.
You're a hostage, captured by terrorists-
(Smiling, chewing) Who, me?
You, anybody - whatever. You're in the little room, you're               chained to the floor, you're there for a long time.. do you think               they would ever consider doing
(Matter-of-factly) They have to, it's in the Geneva Convention.
(Imitating a Turkish terrorist) You! Take off your socks,               your pants, your underwear. We're doing the wash. C'mon! Take it               off, take it off!
Hey, Georgie.
Hi.
(To George) What's the matter?
(Slowly shakes his head) My mother caught me.
"Caught" you? Doing what?
You know. (All three give him blank stares) I was alone..
(Making a face of surprise) You mean..?!
(Nods) Uh-huh.
(Laughing) She caught you?
Where?
(Not really wanting to embellish) ..I stopped by the house               to drop the car off, and I went inside for a few minutes.. Nobody               was there - they're supposed
"Glamour"?
..So, one thing lead to another..
So, what did she do?
First she screams, "George, what are you doing?! My               God!" And it looked like she was gonna faint - she started               clutching the wall, trying to hang onto it.
(Reflecting on the story so far) Man..
I didn't know whether to try and keep her from falling,               or zip up.
What did you do?
I zipped up!
(Wide-eyed) So, she fell?
Yeah. (Noticing this makes him out to be the bad kid, he               gets defensive) Well, I couldn't run over there the way I was!
No, I guess you couldn't have..
(In the middle of Elaine's sentence, smiling) No, I wouldn't               think so.
(Finishing it off) ..done that.
So, she fell, and then she started screaming, "My               back! My back!" So, I picked her up and took her to the hospital.
(Between chuckles) How is she?
(Somewhat angered) She's in traction.
(Still laughing) Ok, I'm sorry.
It's not funny, Elaine.
(Stifling her laughter) I know. I'm sorry. I'm serious.
Her back went out. She's gotta be there for a couple of               days. All she said on the way over in the car was, "Why, George,               why?!".. I said, "Because it's
"Glamour"?
(Vowing) Well, I'll tell you this, though - I am never               doing.. that , again.
What, you mean, in your mother's house, or all together?
(Definite) All together.
Oh, gimme a break..
(Skeptical) Ohhh yeah.. right.
Oh, like you're gonna stop?
C'mon..
You don't think I can?
No chance.
(Daring) You think you could?
Well, I know I could hold out longer than you.
Care to make it interesting?
Sure, how much?
A hundred dollars.
(Pointing) You're on.
(Butting in) Wait a second, wait a second. Count me in               on this. (Clicks his tongue)
You?
Yeah.
You'll be out before we get the check.
(Smiling) I want to be in on this, too.
(Rejecting) Ohh, no. No, no, no..
Why?
(Showing difference) It's apples and oranges..
What? Why? (More 'no, no, no's from Jerry and George. Persistent)               Why?
Because you're a woman!
So what?
It's easier for a woman not to do it than a man.
(Sarcastic) Oh.
We have to do it. It's part of our lifestyle. It's like,               uh.. shaving.
Oh, that is such bologna. I shave my legs.
(Making a point) Not everyday.
Alright, look, you want to be in?
Yeah!
You gotta give us odds. At least two to one - you gotta               put up two-hundred dollars.
No, a thousand!
No, I'll - I'll put up one-fifty.
Alright, you're in for one-fifty.
(Nodding) Okay, one-fifty.
Alright, now, how are we gonna monitor this thing?
Well, obviously, we all know each other very well, (Elaine               slightly laughs) I'm sure that we'll all feel comfortable within               the confines of the honor system.
Alright. (Holds out his pinkie at the center of the table)
Jerry's apartment]
(Stern) No, ma, I'm not gonna see a psychiatrist. N- I               don't care if you do pay for it! No! Discussion over. Yeah, alright,               I'll see you later. Yes, of course
(Waits for the rest of the sentence) ..Yeah?
(Defensively) Whatever.
How is she?
(Shrugging it off) She'll be fine. I gotta go to the hospital               to see her tonight.
(Answering to the intercom) Yeah?
It's me.
Come on up. (Lets her in by unlocking the front door)
Hey, what are you doing tonight?
(Opens his door slightly for Elaine) Dating Marla.
Oh, the virgin?
Yeah.
Any, uh.. progress, there? What's the latest?
Well, I got my troops amassed along the border - I'm just               waiting for someone to give me the go-ahead.
Hey, look at this, c'mere. There's a naked woman across               the street.
Where?
Second floor from the top. (Pointing) See the window on               the left?
(In awe) Wow!
(Also amazed) Who walks around the house like that?!
(Suggesting) Maybe she's a nudist. You know, those nudist               colony people..
..Yeah.. (Pause) yeah.. (Slowly stands up, and walks out               Jerry's apartment - leaving Jerry and George with the view, he shuts               the door behind him)
Hey, let me ask you a question. In these nudist colonies,               do they eat naked in the dining room?
I would imagine it's all naked.
What about the chamber maids? Are they naked, too?
(Still focused on the nudist) They're naked, the gardeners               naked.. the bellhops. (Jerry makes a noise of astonishment) One               big nude-a-rama.

Well you can wait for them outside.
Yeah I guess I'd better. Wouldn't want to take any attention               away
All right, All right. Out, Out.
What ever you say Cro..w-well!
What's going on over here?
There is a beached whale, she's dying.
Is anyone here a marine biologist?
Here is the latest draft. I see you next week. Same time,               same
It was nice meeting you, real pleasure!
Oh, by the way Mr. Testikov do you remember the other day               when we
How could I forget?
Well would you believe that it hit actually somebody in               the head.
Right in the head!
Boing!
(Shouting)What is that noise!
Um ,nothing.
What is the noise!
Hey that's my purse!
A recorder!
No that's a radio..
You were spying on me!
No I wasn't.
Come on! Save the whale! Hurry up it's gonna die!
Save the whale George... for me.
So I started to walk into the water. I won't lie to you               boys, I
George I was just reading this thing in the papers, it's               amazing!
I know I was just telling them the story.
Come on George, finish the story.
The sea was angry that day my friends, like an old man               trying to
I got about fifty-feet out and then suddenly the great               beast
Mammal.
Whatever.
Well, what did you do next?

Then from out of nowhere a huge title wave lifted, tossed               like a cork and I found myself on top of him face to face with the blow-hole. I could barely see from all of the waves crashing down               on top of me but I knew something was there so I reached my hand and pulled out the obstruction!
What is that a Titleist? A hole in one eh.
Well the crowd most have gone wild!
Oh yes they did Jerry they were all over me. It was like               Rocky 1.
Wow! What'd she say?
She told me to "Go to hell!" and I took the bus               home.
All right lets go.
Are you in a bad mood?
No, I just got my laundry back.
Ohhh! GoldenBoy?
He didn't make it.
I'm sorry.
This is GoldenBoy's son, BabyBlue.
What's with you?
Sand. It's everywhere
