line: Christian Fecteau
Monk's coffee shop, evening]
Hum! That was really good!
Yeah. Are you full?
Oh no, I've had just enough.
Here we go... apple pie! Best apple pie in the city. (Jerry         starts eating) Delicious. I'm not waiting for you. Take some.
No thanks.
You're not gonna have any?
No (with a disgusted face)
Do you not like apple pie?
No, it's not that.
Well, at least taste it.
No (a resolute "no")
You won't even taste it?
No.
Come on, try it! (Audrey shakes her head doing "no")         A little taste! (still shaking) Come on! (still shaking)
Jerry's appartment, the next day]
Did she say why?
No. She wouldn't say anything. She just kept shaking her head         like this (Imitating Audrey)
Maybe she's diabetic.
No. She carries Entemanns doughnuts in her purse.
Maybe you said something that offended her.
The only thing I can think of is I told her we should have those         moving walkways all over the city.
Like at the airport? (getting excited)
Yeah.
That's a great idea!!!
Tell me about it!
We could be zipping all over the place.
They could at least try it.
They never try anything.
What's the harm?
No harm!
(still talking to George) I'm sorry. There's no reason         for her not to taste that pie.
Who wouldn't taste a pie?
Audrey.
Dump her.
Boy, I never broke up with anyone for not tasting pie???
(piffling) I once broke up with someone for not offering         me pie.
You did?
He could be eating a Hero, he wouldn't offer me anything. It's         a sickness.
Well, I can't walk anywhere now. I just gonna be wishing there         were walkways. (seeing Elaine removing her shoe) What are you doing?
I got a pebble.
Boy, I never heard of that happening to a woman?
What the hell does that mean?
Hey! Elaine. Go Like this. (imitating a mannequin posture)
What? Why?
Do it. Do it. This.
Like... (doing it) Like this?
Oh yeah! It's you!
What's me?
(to the gang) There's a clothing store downtown. They         got a mannequin in there that looks exactly like Elaine.
Get out!
It's uncanny! It's like they chopped off your arms and legs,         dipped you in plastic, and screwed you back all together, and stuck you         on a pedestal. It's really quite exquisite.
Kramer, what's the name of the store with the mannequin?
Rinitze. (he takes Jerry's spatula and starts rubbing his         back with it) Oh yeah...
(to Kramer) Uh... may I help you? (wondering what the         hell's Kramer doing)
It's this itch. I was watching TV without my shirt on, and one         my couch cushion didn't have any fabric on it.
Wait a minute, Rinitze? Don't they have somme really cool suits         in there?
Real Boss!
I'm going down there.
I'm gonna go with you. I gotta get a new suit. I got a second         interview with MacKenzie, and I think I'm really close. They're all taking         me out to lunch on Friday.
(grabbing George by the arm, hurried to leave) Let's go.
All right. All right. (They both leave)
(leaving too, with the spatula) Are you gonna need this?
Rinitze]
It looks exactly like me.
It's like some pod landed from another planet and took your body.         Don't fall asleep Elaine.
What's going on here? How do you think this happened?
Whoa, look at this. This is a beautiful suit. Huh?
You think that could be a coincidence George? Is that possible?
(european accent) You are perfect for that suit.
You think so?
(to the saleswoman) Excuse me. Where did this come from?
I don't know.
You really think this looks O.K. on me?
Fabulous. Perfect fit. And it's the last one we have.
I'm sorry. You can't tell me where the mannequin came from?
I told you, I don't know.
(irritated, but still polite) Well, is there somebody         around here I could talk to who would know?
Why?
Isn't it obvious? This mannequin looks exactly like me.
(upset) Did you just roll your eyes at him? Because let         me tell you something, if anobody should be rolling their eyes, it is         me at him about you.
I think maybe you're flattering yourself. That mannquein         is wearing a 1200$ Gaultier dress.

What are you saying, that I'm not good enough for this hideous         dress? (looking at her name tag) Listen Natasha... I wouldn't be         caught dead wearing your crummy little euro-trash rags. (to George)         I'll meet you outside.
What is her problem?
Pfft! What can you do? (looking at a tag on the suit)         Is this the price tag?
Yes.
Yes, hello. Party's over. (taking off the suit)
I'll tell you a little secret. We're having an unadvertised         sale starting Friday, that suit will be half-price.
So you think you can put the suit aside and hold it for me?
Oh, I'm afraid I could't do that. It wouldn't be fair to         the other customers.
Oh yes, of course, and we have to be fair. (placing the suit         further away in the rack)
Monk's]
So, I found out who supplies the mannequins and I called 'em         up.
How did they get your face?
I don't know. They wouldn't tell me. (Jerry is not listening,         he's looking at two women sitting in the other booth) Jerry? Je...         Hello?
(Jerry gets up and walk to these persons) Uh... Excuse         me. I couldn't help but notice you offered her a piece of your pie.
That's right.
And you waved it away.
Right.
Did you give her a reason?
Yes, I was full.
You were full. So you gave a reason. You didn't just shake your         head.
No, I'm not a psycho.
Exactly. You're not a psycho. You've been very helpful. Thank         you very much. Allow me to leave the tip. (sits back with Elaine and         Kramer) Well, I think we proven who the psycho is.
We certainly have.
Hey, Elaine scratch my back.
No way!
Come on, one lap around.
No.
It will be a funky adventure.
Kramer, forget it.
Jerry, how about you?
I think you know my policy.
I'm going home to spatula. (picks up the check and walks to         the cashier)
I thought George was meeting us here?
No he's going downtown to guard the suit.
He's guarding a suit?
(to Kramer) Do you need some help         with that itch?
Madam, I pray you're not toying with me. (Olive shows her         long finger nails) Whoa.
Turn around.
Oh, all right. (Olive scratches, Kramer enjoys, Elaine and         Jerry watch.)
Rinitze]
(makes a guy trying the suit. His name is not mentionned         but it seems to be Bob as it appears in the credits at the end of the         episode.) It fits you perfectly.
You think so? (she nods and walks away)

(outside, looking the guy trying the suit through the window,         and thinking out loud) What's this? Can't I leave this place for a         second? (goes in, take off his jacket, walks to the guy and talks to         him with an european accent) Can I help you?
I'm buying the suit.
No, no, no, this suit is not for sale. (tries to take off         the suit from the guy)
Excuse me, do you work here?
(leaving the european accent) No.
Then what the hell business is it of yours?
Look, I'm doing you a favor. They're having an unadvertised sale.         This suit is gonna be half-priced starting ... Monday.
Really? This Monday?
Yes. Now take off those pants.
Actually, the unadvertised sale starts on Friday.
Friday? Thanks. (Gives a dirty look at George and leaves)
(to the saleswoman) You know honey for an unadvertised         sale, you're doing a lot of yapping about it.
Poppie's restaurant]
I can't beleive your father owns this place. So how are the desserts         here?
Everything is delicious.
You've tasted them?
Um-hmm, I think almost all of them.
Oh I see they have apple pie.
Mmm-hmm.
You've had the apple pie?
Many times.

Audrey, I got to be honest with you. I'm a very curious guy. It's         my nature. I need to know things. Not tasting the apple pie the other         day, I can't get past it. You obviously like pies. You carry doughnuts         in your bag, you're not averse to pastry. Surely you could see how such         a thing would prey on my mind.
Can we drop this?
(like a frustrated child) Why can't I know?
Ah! Poppie.
Sweetheart, hello.
Poppie, this is Jerry.
Welcome (shakes Jerry's hand)
Hello Poppie.
Don't fill up on the bread. I'm making you a very special dinner.         Very special. (he leaves)
The pies. I'm going to the bathroom. You know. (he leaves)
Ah, Jerry! Tonight you in for a real treat. I'm personnaly going         to prepare the dinner for you and my Audrey.
Jerry are you OK?
Huh?
Is anything wrong?
No, Nothing.
You look like you've seen a ghost.
Monk's]
(to another cashier) I'll see you tomorrow.
Hey. These are for you Olive.
Thank you.
Ohh!
Poppie's]
Here it is.
Wait till you taste this. (she eats) Poppie, this is perfect.
(to Jerry) Well?
Jerry have some.
You're not gonna taste it?
Jerry.
Jerry's appartment]
So she tought I did it to get back at her
Why didn't you just tell her?
I don't think that's the kind of thing you wanna hear about your         father. But I'll tell you when he came out of that bathroom and he was         kneading that dough, it was a wild scene.
How could he not have washed?
Even if you're not gonna soap up, at least pretend for my benefit.         Turn the water on, do something.
Yeah, just like I do.
You know a chef who doesn't wash is like a cop who steals. It's         a cry for help, he wants to get caught.
Well, I think Poppie's got some problems. There's a whole other         thing going on with Poppie. So how did you leave ti?
We haven't spoken.
Well, I'm not gonna need this anymore. I got Olive. (Jerry         throws out the spatula)
Olive?

Yeah. My lady friend down at Monks. You guys ought to see the         way she works her nails across my back. Ohh! She's a maestro. The crisscross.         The figure eight, strummin' the ol' banjo, and this wild, savage free-for-all         where anything can happen.
I got to get downtown and buy that suit. The store opens in twenty         minutes.
Is that Elaine mannequin still there?
Yeah. The last time I saw her, she was naked.
Yeah, and Poppie's got problems...
Rinitze]
Where is it? Where is it?
(George takes out the suit from the other rack) Well,         look at this. (innocently) This doesn't belong here! Someone has         made a terrible mistake.
You bastard! You hid the suit.
Hid? I have no idea how this suit got misplaced. Nevertheless,         I do believe I shall purchase it.
I hope you rot in that suit. I'm gonna get you for this. I don't         know how, but I'm gonna get you. You are going to pay!
Oh, I'll pay. Half-price. Arrivederci my fellow 40-short.
Monks]
So I made a little list of people who might've made the mannequin.         You know, possible suspects.
Yeah, all right. Go ahead. (not very interested)
There's this blind guy at a party I was at, and he felt my face         for a really long time. You know, to see what I looked like. He almost         put his finger up my nose.
Hum... ok, what else you got?
OK, I'm not gonna tell you the rest of the list.
Oh, because I didn't think the blind guy did it?
Because you have an attitude.
Oh!
Georgio! Nice duds!
You're telling me. (he walks around and the suit makes a swooshing         sound) So, what do you think?
Did you hear something?
Yeah, like a swoosh.
Yeah.
It must be the fabric. It's rubbing between you thighs when you         walk. That's what's making that swooshy sound.
I probably didn't hear it on the way over because of the street         noise. (he panics) This is no good! I got to meet these guys from         MacKenzie for lunch in half an hour!
So what? What would they care?
This MacKenzie, he's a bit of a nut. Someone told me he fired         the last guy because his nose whistled when he breathed.
So you think you're not gonna get the job because your pants make         a noise?
Let's say it comes down to me and one other guy. He's got a nice         quiet suit, and I'm whooshing all over the place! Who do you think he's         gonna hire?
You know, I think all these interviews are making you nuts.
Hey Jerry, I saw your girlfriend was in here before.
Audrey?
Yep. Sat down, had herself a piece of pie.
Was it apple?
What else?
This woman is bending my mind into a pretzel!
Do I know you?
Hmm... No you don't.
Yeah! You were wearing a G-string and one of those bras with         points.
The mannequin!
Oh, I got to see this thing.
Rinitze]
Boy, the resemblance is uncanny.
You think you can pose me however you want? That's my ass in         your window!
It's our store and our mannequin, we can do whatever we want         with it.
No! You take down that mannequin right now, or I'm pressing charges.         (Jerry goes along) Yes, this is my attorney.
(to Jerry) Yeah? What law am I breaking?
Well, I believe there's some legal precedent - Winchell vs. Mahoney,
Uh-huh
The Charlie Macarthy hearings.
Uh-huh. Are you taking this down?
I'm getting the manager. (she leaves)
Jerry get the car. (she's getting the mannequin)
What are you doing?
Just get the car!
Elaine, as your legal counsel I must advise against this.
Jerry's car]
I don't know about you, but I'm getting a hankering for some doublemint         gum. I'm dropping you off at work, right?
Where are you going?
Poppie's
a restaurant]

Thanks for meeting me down here George. My office is out of         control, (George's pants are making noise) phones ringing, people         running in and out. (MacKenzie stops talking and walking, George too)         Did you hear something?
No, I didn't hear anything.

Huh, that's strange. (they start walking again) It's         quieter here. We can concentrate without people wooshing around... (he         stops again, George too) That sound again. Sure you didn't hear anything?
No, can't say as I did.
Kind of like a... rustling.
Could be the leaves...
Poppie's]
Hello.
What are you doing here?
So how was the pie?
What pie?
The apple pie you had today at Monks
I'm very busy here.
Pretty good, wasn'it? I told you you should've tasted it.
You better not let Poppie see you here.
All right, I'm looking for someone named Poppie.
Uh, who are you?
Board of health, we've had several complaints.
Oh, about the... uh (Jerry pretend to wash his hands)
Are you Poppie?
I'm Poppie.
I think you'd better come with me.
What's the problem?
What do they want from Poppie?
Well, Poppie's a little sloppy.
at the restaurant with MacKenzie]
You taught I'd care about your pants wooshing?
I heard the last guy got fired because his nose whislted.

No, no, no. He got fired because he wasn't a team player.         That's something we don't joke about at MacKenzie. You'll find we're team         here George. We don't tolerate dissent. If you want to go your own way,         you're in the wrong place.
No problem there. Conformity is an obsession with me.
Chocolate cream pie. Compliments of the house.
Oh! Hope you saved room for dessert.
(to George) The chef said that he made it special for         you.
Mmm.. Best pie I've ever tasted. Take a bite George. (George         shakes his head doing "no") Well, take a bite. It's delicious.         (still shaking) I insist. (still shaking)
If you're one of us, you'll take a bite.
Monk's]
So you didn't get the job.
No. But I was the only one at the table that didn't get violently         ill.
Kramer, you can't keep avoiding her like this, you're gonna have         to say something.
What am I supposed to say?
Tell her you lost your itch.
What happened to your itch?
I lost it two days ago. I've been faking it so I wouldn't hurt         her feelings.
Well you should tell her.
I'll let her down easy. All right. (he gets up and walks to         Olive) Well, hi Olive. (she reaches for Kramer's back) No,         no. No more of that. There's something I have to tell you.
What?
Uh, well, there's someone else.
Someone else?
Yeah, yeah, yeah...
Who is she?
Her. (he points to the Elaine mannequin in Jerry's car)
her?
Yeah, there she is. That's my gal.
You're a liar. I've seen her in here before. She's not your girlfriend.
Now Olive, look, I'm sorry.
Why is she wearing her underwear?
Well, it's a style. (turns back to Jerry) Jerry give me         the keys. (Jerry throws his keys to Kramer) Well, I guess we're         gonna go for a drive now. She really loves that.
Did you ever solve the riddle of the pie?
No. That's one for the ages. But I think they're gonna put Poppie         away for a long long time.

You guys are not gonna believe this. I just got a letter from         a friend of mine in Chicago who's shopping, and she said she saw a mannequin         that looked just like me. What if there're more. Where are they coming         from?
The building where Ricky works. Ricky's the guy in "The         Cigar Store Indian" who made a bouquet for Elaine from Frank's TV         guide.]
Ricky, we've been getting a tremendous response to your         TR-6 mannequin.
TR-6? I prefer to think of her as... Elaine.

Courtney Cox (Meryl)        Scott LaRose (Greg)        Joseph Ragno (Marty)        Liz Sheridan (Helen)        Barney Martin (Morty)        Rebecca Glenn (Paula)        Len Lesser (Uncle Leo)        Lili Bernard (Anna)        Nick LaTour (Grandpa)        Susan Segal (Waitress)        Lawrence A. Mandley (Coffee shop owner)

Of all the places that you go all the time,         the dry-cleaning relationship is one of the most bizarre. Because you         keep giving each other the same thing, back and forth, over and over again.         He gives it to you, you give it to him, he gives it back to you. It's         like it's half his shirt, in a way. He has it as much as you do...you         oughta go shopping with him. 'What do you think of this shirt?' 'That         would look good with a light starch.' The only warning label people really         respect is 'dry-clean only.' Y'know what I mean? Speed limits, lung cancer,         cigarette warnings - your very life is at stake! People go, 'Ah, the hell         with it!' But dry-clean only? 'Oh, don't put that in the wash! It's dry-clean         only! Are you crazy?!'
Good morning.
Good morning.
How'd you sleep?
Hey, you are the couch tonight, young lady. You were all over         my side.
I was not!
C'mon, I was sleeping with one cheek off the bed!
By the way, you're falling way behind on the 'I love you's.'
No, it's 15-8.
I know I can't beat ya, I'm just trying to stay competitive.
Alright c'mon, let's get some breakfast.

Uh, let me get a coat. I think I'll try a sport jacket and scarf         thing, you know, like an unemployed actor. <Goes into his room, and         comes back out with the jacket on.> Haven't worn this one in a long         time.
Ooh, cashmere?
No, gore-tex. It's new. <Checks his pockets.> Hey, look         at this locket. What the hell is this? There's a picture in here, look         at that.
Wow, this is really old. You don't know whose it is?
No, I haven't worn this jacket since I got it back from the dry-cleaner.         Maybe we should ask him.
Alright, we'll stop over there.
Yeah. What do you want to get for breakfast?
Pancakes.
Oh now, c'mon, you know I'm getting pancakes.
I don't know that!Â
But we can't both get pancakes, it's embarrassing. It's like one         step from the couples who dress alike.
I'll get the short stack.
Ah, that's why I love ya. 15-9. <They go out into the hallway         and run into Kramer and his African-American girlfriend, Anna.> Hey,         how ya doin.'
We just got back from breakfast. The pancakes were dynamite.
Hey, is that my maple syrup? <Kramer hands it over.>
You bring your own syrup?
Got to.
You got a lot to learn about pancakes.
This is my wife. She died eight years         ago. I been looking all over for this!
Boy, it's a lucky thing I put the jacket on. But how did it get         in the pocket?
Well, see here, the chain is broken...it must have slipped in         when I was, uh...<gestures at the racks of clothes behind him.>
Oh, wow.
I turned my house upside-down looking for this! It's all I have         left of her.
Oh, that's so touching.
Know what I'm gonna do for you? I'm gonna give you         and your family 25% off all your dry-cleaning from now on.
Oh, come on!
What are you talkin' about?
It's silly!
Hey, forget it!
Get outta here!
It's done!
Alright.
Well, I guess I get it too, because I'm his wife.
I didn't know you were married.
Oh...yeah...you've never met my wife, Meryl? Meryl Seinfeld.
Sure, you get the discount, too.
You might regret that, because the money my wife spends on clothes...
I'm taking him to the cleaners!

Ah - see the sense of humor? C'mere, I'm so nuts about you...<hugs         Meryl.> I tell ya, it was fun being single, but when you meet a woman         like this, you don't walk to get married - you run!
Oh, hi Greg.
Haven't seen you in a while.
Yeah. Well, today was the first day I worked out since the Central         Park Mini-Marathon.
You ran the Mini-Marathon?
No, but I exercised that day. <Laughs.>
Well, I gotta take off.
Yeah, I guess as an airline pilot, you're one of the few people         who can say that and mean it. <Laughs again. Greg looks at her, unamused.>         Um, do you have the time?
Eleven-thirty.
Eleven-thirty?
Wait, ten-thirty. Sorry.
Oh.
Do you have to be somewhere?
No.
Then what are you doing?
I'm just waiting for my friend George, we worked out together.
Oh. Well, it was good seeing you.
Yeah, nice to see you, too.
Uh, would you, um...can I...
Pardon?
The syrup. Would you pass the syrup?
Oh, you want to try the syrup! <Meryl         smiles and takes it. The waitress comes over.>
Can I get you anything else?
Um, yeah...I think my wife and I'll have a little more coffee.
Okay.
And a check for my husband.
To my beautiful wife.
To my adoring husband.
Adoring? What about handsome?
I like adoring.
Sure, adoring's good for you, what does it do for me? <Meryl         laughs. The owner of the coffee shop comes over.>

character: OWNER (points at the bottle of maple syrup)
line: Excuse me...where did you         get that?
I, uh...well...
Uh, we don't allow any outside syrups, jams or condiments in the         restaurant. (To Jerry) And if I catch you in here with that again...I         will confiscate it.
Well, I told my wife not to bring it.
Really? 25% off? Do I get that, too?
No, just Meryl.
Why, why? Why does she get it?
"My wife has an inner ear infection."
See?
I like that! Hey look, will you do me a favor? Will you take         my quilt into the cleaners for me, so I can get the discount too?
Oh come on, we're gonna start doing this now? I can't be taking         all your dry-cleaning in!
C'mon, just this one time! It's expensive!
Alright. <Elaine enters.>
Hey. Hey Elaine, what do you say if neither of us is married         in ten years, we get hitched?
Let's make it fifty.
We're engaged! Alright, I'm gonna get my quilt. <Kramer leaves.>
Alright, listen to this. Remember that guy I was telling you         about at the health club?
The fly-boy.
Yeah.
Hey, where's George? I thought he was with you.
I waited, he didn't show up. Anyway, this guy gave me an open-lip         kiss.
So?
So? We've always just kind've pecked. This one had a totally         different dynamic.
Really.
Yeah. I mean, his upper lip landed flush on my upper lip. But         his lower lip landed well below my rim.
Moisture?
Yeah. Definite moisture.
That's an open-lip kiss, alright.
Yeah. Listen, I think he's giving me a big signal...maybe he         wants to change our relationship. <The buzzer sounds, Elaine answers         it.> Yeah?
Oh, uh...it's George.
Hey, what happened to you?
Nothing...little problem.
Well, what was it? I mean, I was waiting.
Can I come upstairs, please? <Elaine pushes the button and         lets George in.>
I mean, maybe he wants to ask me out.
I don't know why you're interested in this guy, he's a jerk.
Because, he doesn't pay any attention to me, and he ignores me.
Yeah, so?
I respect that. <George enters.> Mmm, what happened?
Nothing, I... said it was a little problem.
Yeah? What was it?
Well...I was in the locker room showering, and I...I         had to go, so...
Here we go.
Anyway, I think the guy in the shower opposite saw me. He gave         me a dirty look.
You went...in the shower?
Yeah, so what? I'm not the only one! <Kramer enters with his         quilt.>
Do you go in the shower?
No, never.
Do you?
I take baths.
Well, what was I supposed to do? Get out of the shower, put on         my bathrobe? Go all the way down to the other end? Come all the way back?
Ever hear of...holding it in?
Oh, no...no, that's very bad for the kidneys.
How do you know?
Medical journals!
Do the medical journals mention anything about standing in a pool         of someone else's urine?
Hello.
Oh, hi...honey.
What are you doing here?
I just thought I'd drop off a few things.
Oh. <Smiles at Marty nervously.> Well, I must have been         in the incinerator room when you left. Here you go, Marty. <Hands over         Kramer's quilt.>
Another quilt? Huh? <Uncle Leo enters.>
Jerry!
Uncle Leo!
Hello!
Hello.
So, if you or your wife want to drop by on Wednesday,         it should be ready.
Your wife?

character: JERRY (hoping Leo will pick up on the scam)
line: Yeah...my wife.
What are you talking about?
Uh...I got married.
You got married? I wasn't invited? Nobody sends         me an invitation?
Well, it was sudden.
Are you ashamed of your uncle? Do I embarrass you?
No, no, it was a small ceremony.
Haven't I always been a good uncle?
Yes, yes, you have.
Who told you when you went to school that you print well?
You did, you did.
When he was younger, he had a beautiful penmanship.         I used to encourage him to print.
I'm a good printer.

I remember your 'V.' It was like a perfect triangle. Whoa,         there's my bus! <Rushes out.> Hello! Wait! <Jerry tries to catch         Leo before he runs off to tell him about his "pretend marriage,"         but doesn't make it.>
I'm glad you're here. This can get really boring. Do you know where         I can get some good olives?
I can find out.
Would ya?
Sure. <Thinks - Ooh, a project. That's a definite signal!>
By the way, you look really great in that leotard.
Oh, thanks. <Thinks - That's no signal, who wouldn't like         me in this leotard? I look amazing in this leotard.>
Hey, you know what's weird? I think I had a dream about you last         night.
<Thinks - Okay, he open-lips me, he dreams about me, we         have an olive project...that's it, I'm asking this guy out.> Um,         you know Greg, I...
Can I have a sip of your water?
Oh, yeah, sure. <Hands Greg her bottle.>
Thanks. <Is about to take a drink, but wipes the neck of the         bottle with his shirt first.>
<Thinks - Oh my God.>
I'm sorry, what were you saying?
It was nothing, forget it. <George enters the gym.>

See that guy right there? I caught him urinating in the shower.         I'm thinking about turning him in, too. <On the other side of the room,         George falls off an exercise machine and gets his foot caught in it.>
Honey? Could you get me something to drink?

character: JERRY (from his bedroom hallway, alluding to the fact that she should         get the drink herself)
line: You're right there.
C'mon, I'm sitting! <Jerry walks to the kitchen, annoyed. Meryl         laughs at the TV show she's watching.>
Honey, what'd you do with the can opener?
I didn't do anything with it.
Well, it's not here, it was here yesterday.
It's in the first drawer.
I'm looking in the first drawer. It's not here.
Yes, it is.
Hey...I'm not stupid. I'm looking in that drawer,         there's no can opener.
Did I say you were stupid?

Well, wouldn't I have to be? You tell me there's a can         opener in the drawer, I'm looking in the drawer, there's no can opener         - what other conclusion could one reach? <The phone rings.>
Do you want me to go find it?
Yes. I do. You show me where there's a can         opener in that drawer. <Answers the phone.> Hello! I'm sorry, I'm         just fighting with my wife.
Jerry, we just heard, what's going on?
Why the hell didn't you tell us?
Listen, Ma...
It was in here yesterday!
Yeah, that's what I said!
Who is she? When did this happen?
I told her you'd get married. She thought you'd never         do it.
Morty, you're talking too loud.
I'm not talking loud!
You're hurting my eardrum.
Well, you must have done something         with it!
I'm on the phone!
Is she there? Can we talk to her? What's her name?
Mom, I'm not married.
What?
I'm not married!
I knew it, I told ya!
Uncle Leo said.
I'm just pretending I'm married to get a discount on dry-cleaning.
A discount on dry-cleaning?

character: JERRY (to Meryl, who's making a racket in the kitchen looking for the         can opener)
line: Could you make a little more noise? <To his parents>         Listen, I'm gonna have to call you later.
Well, I give up.
Well, whoopie whoop. <Meryl goes into the other room. Kramer         staggers in the door in his bathrobe.>
Got any coffee?
Yeah. <Kramer lurches into the kitchen, trips, and falls onto         the kitchen floor.> I'll get it, I'll get it! Take it easy, why are         you so tired?

My quilt is still at the cleaners. Jerry, I can't sleep without         my quilt. Like the other night? I was cold. So, last night, I turn up         the heat - it's too hot. I open up a window - it's too cold. <Frantic>         I can't get into a zone!
What is that? <Points to Kramer's pocket as Meryl comes back.>
Oh, I forgot. <Hands back Jerry's can opener.>
Hey, I'm sorry about all that can opener stuff.
Yeah, me too. Love you.
Love you.
Well, goodnight.
Goodnight. <They kiss goodnight, then promptly roll away from         each other and go to sleep.>
They could kick me out of the health club if he tells them!
So what do you want me to do?
Talk to him!
How can I do that?
You said the guy gave you an open-lipped kiss!

character: ELAINE (enunciating clearly so George gets the point)
line: Yes, but then         he wiped his hand on the top of the bottle when I offered him water!
Well, that doesn't mean anything!
Are you kidding? That's very significant! If he was interested         in me, he'd want my germs! He'd just crave my germs!
She's right, George. Bottle-wipe is big.
Well, what about the open-lipped kiss?
Bottle-wipe supercedes it.
Yeah, you're right, you're right. <To Elaine> Alright,         maybe he's not interested, but you still know him - can't you just ask         him?
George...but if I ask him now, I will have no chance of going         out with him.
Why?
I...I don't know...
Aha. Aha. Could it be because you don't want him to know that         you have a friend who pees in the shower, is that it?!
No, that's not it!
Oh, I think it is! I think that's exactly what it is!
Why couldn't you just wait?
I was there! I saw a drain!
Since when is a drain a toilet?!
It's all pipes! What's the difference?!
Different pipes go to different places! You're gonna mix 'em         up!
I'll call a plumber right now! <Goes for the phone.>
Alright, can we just drop all the pee-pipe stuff here?
Okay! Okay! I will talk to him. <Kramer enters.>
Jerry, I think that quilt is ready.
Alright.
Well, you gotta pick it up for me!
Alright, I'll pick it up, but it's the last time I'm doin' it!
I'm so tired!
Boy, you don't look good.
Huh? I don't?
No, you look pale.
Pale? Oh my God...I gotta meet Anna's parents today! <The         phone rings.>

Hello? Oh, hi honey. <annoyed, weary> Yes, I told him. I'll         get it. <George and Elaine give each other a look, then leave Jerry         to argue with Meryl on the phone.> Whenever. Okay, I'm sorry...
I'm sorry, it's not ready yet. <Kramer bursts in.>
Not ready? It has to be ready! What kind of a business are you         running here?
Who the hell are you? It's not your quilt.
He's a very good friend of mine, he's kind've like an older brother         to me...when things don't go right, he kinda takes it personally.
Well, uh...maybe tomorrow.
Maybe.
Oh, it's okay, it'll be okay.
Alright, I'm gonna see you later.
Where you goin'?
I gotta meet Anna's parents today, remember? I look terrible!         I'm gonna hit the tanning machines.
I can't believe you still do that. You know those things are bad         for ya.
Hey, that's how I maintain my glow.
I'm goin' home. <Kramer exits. An attractive woman enters the         dry-cleaners with a bundle of clothes in her hands. Jerry notices her         and waits by the door.>

character: PAULA (to Marty, in a foreign accent)
line: Excuse me? Uh, how much would         it cost to clean this?
Oh, about thirteen dollars.
Thirteen? Well, I can't afford that.
Well, I'm sorry.
Hi, Greg.
Hey, Elaine. I'll be off in a second. <Another guy approaches         the exercise machine.>
I got the machine next, buddy. <Greg finishes up his workout         and gets off the machine.>
It's all yours. <Walks away. Elaine looks at the         machine, then George runs over.>
What happened? Did he bring it up?
Never mind that, look at the signal I just got.
Signal? What signal?
Lookit. He knew I was gonna use the machine next, he didn't wipe         his sweat off. That's a gesture of intimacy.
I'll tell you what that is - that's a violation of club rules.         Now I got him! And you're my witness!
Listen, George! Listen! He knew what he was doing, this was a         signal.
A guy leaves a puddle of sweat, that's a signal?
Yeah! It's a social thing.
What if he left you a used Kleenex, what's that, a valentine?         Now you go up to him and you tell him that if he's thinking of turning         me in, that I got the goods on him!
No! I won't be a party to this.
So you're gonna let me get suspended for shower urination?
Okay, I'll talk to him. But you're putting me in a very difficult         position. <Walks away.>
I won't let you do this!
I want to!
But it isn't right! I can't.
Give me the clothes.
Jerry, please. What about her?
Oh, the hell with her. <Paula dramatically flees from the coffee         shop. Jerry thinks for a second, then follows her and catches up to her         on the street.>
No, Jerry, please!
I'm not gonna let you walk out of my life.
I can't fight you. <They embrace and         kiss passionately.>
Do you want box or hanger?
You decide. <Jerry considers.>
You're really working up quite a sweat today, huh?
Yeah. <Spies the shapely manager of the health club.> Oh,         there's the manager. Good. I think I'm gonna talk to her about that guy,         you know, we cannot have people like that in here.
Are you sure you want to do that?
Yeah. He's disgusting! Besides, I'll take any chance I can to talk         to her.
You're interested in...in her? <Points at the manager.>
Very.
Ah. You know, uh...I'm engaged. <preens> Yep, gettin' married         in fifty years. <Snaps the straps of her leotard against her chest         and winces. George walks by the manager.>
Oh good, there he is. I wanna be able to point him out.
You know, Greg, I wouldn't do that if I were you.
Why?
Well, correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't it a violation of club         policy to not wipe down a machine after using it?
Oh, I see...you're friends with the urinator, aren't you?
Yeah, well, at least he had a drain.
Here you go, Mrs. Seinfeld...with your 25% discount, it comes         to $17.80.
Here you go. <Pays Marty, then looks at the clothes on the         hanger.> Excuse me, this isn't mine.
Oh, yes it is. Your husband brought it in himself.
Really? <Takes her change and grabs the clothes off the hanger.>         Thank you. <Exits.>
That's him! <Opens the door. Kramer stands there, deeply         tanned and smiling. Anna and her grandfather are shocked.>
You son of a bitch!
I'm sorry.
Who is she? I want to know who she is.
It doesn't matter. I want a divorce.
A divorce? Oh, so you can marry her and give her the discount?
Yes, that's right.
What happened to us, Jerry?
I'll tell you what happened. We got married.
I'm sorry, this is my fault. I pushed it on you.
No. I guess I just wasn't ready for the responsibilities of a         pretend marriage.
Goodbye, Jerry. Oh, I forgot...<reaches in her purse>...this         is your maple syrup.
It's alright, I want you to have it.
Okay, thanks.
We'll always have...pancakes.
Bye, Jerry. <Exits.>
I thought you said you was bringin' a white boy home!         I don't see a white boy! I see a damn fool!

Not for another three days.

She lives with her parents.

The baldies

(grabs Joey to stop him) Ya alright Joey that's enough, let's go         (walking over to the counter) See ya.

(acting like Joey) Wouldn't you like to pass the ketchup to someone         like me? Please?

Oh, n-no comparison.

Yea?
So I tell Alec that I have to goto Paris for an undetermined         amount of time. Then all I have to do is buy some post cards and have         your parents mail them from Paris.

Who?
Ah, I think he's probably better off.

But there are no stamps on these.
Well no not yet, you gotta buy french stamps (pauses) I-I'll         reimburse you of course.
Why are you doing this?
He wants this guy to think he's in Paris.
Why?
Because George is a deeply disturbed individual.
Oh hey, Helen uh, Could I uh, use some more of your hand lotion?
I told you it was good. (hands Kramer the lotion)
(putting on the lotion) Ya
It's from the Sachs Fifth Avenue in Miami.
Mmm (smelling the lotion as he rubs it in) I'm gonna remember         that if I'm ever in Florida.
Ya, or if you're ever on Fifth Avenue here in New York City, you         could get some there.
Ya
Say those are some nice pants. I got a pair just like them at         home.

Well uh that doesn't surprise me, ya i bought these at Rudy's.         It's a used clothing store. See when people like you die, the widows they         bring in their wardrobes, they make a bundle.
Really? My father has a ton of old clothes just sitting up in         the attic, y-you think they're worth something?
Ya if they're vintage, and you're a widow.
What happens if the husband dies after the wife, who brings in         the clothing in then?
Well I suppose the children do.
(pondering) Yes I suppose they do.
(takes another smell of his hands) Alright I gotta a ten o'clock,         I'll see everybody later.
(grabbing his jacket) Hey oo, I just remembered uh my parents         really wanna have you guys over for dinner before you leave town. What         about tonight?
Tonight?
Yea they're making Payaya.
(looking at Morty) Uh oh I don't think we think we can make it         tonight, (turns toward George) we have plans.
(watching the whole conversation from his desk) What plans?
(turns to Jerry) We have plans.
Where'd you get plans?
(annoyed) We have plans.
Well um, what about tomorrow night?
(turns back toward George) Maybe
Ok uh, I guess I'll tell them that.
(to George as he is about to leave) Hey give 'em our best though.
(quietly) Ya.
(walking over toward George and the door) I'll call you later.
Ya.
So what plans do you have?
None
So how come you're not going over there for dinner?
Jerry we don't care much for the Costanzas'.
We can't stand them.
Really? Since when?
Since always. We've never liked them.
Why?
Well they're so loud, they're always fighting it's uncomfortable,         you never notice?
No I notice but they're from your age group I didn't know you         could detect abnormal behavior among your own kind.
Well we do.
Ya?
It's us.
U-oh come on up. (buzzes them up) It's Elaine you don't have a         problem with her do you?
We adore Elaine.
She wants to say hi, she's with her new boyfriend.
What's he like?
He's nice, bit of a close talker.
A what?
You'll see. (pause) Boy, I had no idea you felt this way about         the Costanzas'
They're exhausting it's like being in an Asylum.
Hi.
Hello Elaine
This is Aaron.
Hello Aaron
Hello.
(getting up in Helen's face) So how long you folks in town?
Oh, three more days, three more days then we're off to Paris.
Ah
We're going with a select charter group.
I love France, (moving over to Morty's face) I was just there         last year. In fact, you know I still have an envelope full of French Franks,         I'll give 'em to ya.
We can't take money.
Oh, no, it's a gift. (looking toward Elaine) from us.
Oh, that is soo nice (very elaborate nice) Aaron. Isn't he nice?         (to Helen) So listen has Jerry been showin' you a good time?
No I haven't.
You know (to Morty) I have a friend who works at the Metropolitan         Museum of Art. How would you like a behind the scenes tour?
(grabbing Aaron) Really, you could do that?
(up in Helen's face) Easily
I wouldn't be any trouble?
(gets closer) Of course not.
When would we go?
How about right now?
I'm ready
Are you sure?
Yes.
Ok, let me get my coat.
(walking over to Elaine and getting into her face) Elaine what         do you say?
W-well I don't think so Aaron, uh, I have plans.
Oh. (getting into Jerry's face) How about you Jerry?
I'm swamped.
You sure? You could examine the art work up close.
Maybe I'll try and catch up with you.
(under her breath) Ya that'll happen)
(Moving toward the door) Alright. We're off.
Ok, bye.
Bye.
Ok buh bye. Have a good time.
Bye.
See everybody later (Morty and Helen leave; Aaron closes the door         blowing Elaine a kiss)
Ok.
Why would he ask your parents to go to a museum?
I don't know.
What is that?
Maybe he was just trying to be nice.
Have you ever heard of anyone doing anything like this?
Wait a second, he just did me a big favor.
What?
(dialing) He got em out of the house.
What?
Call Rachel.
Oh.
(on the phone) ah no, I got the machine. Rachel! Are you there?!         I got the place to myself for a few hours! Rachel! Where are you? Rachel!         (hangs up the phone very disappointed)
(putting on lipstick) Sorry pal, wish I could help you out.
They're not coming?
No, they had plans.
How could they have plans?
That's what I wanna know.
Well what difference does it make? They wouldn't lie to us, they're         are dear friends.
What am I supposed to do with all this Paella?
They said tomorrow, maybe.
Maybe?
Maybe they don't like us.
Why wouldn't they like us? (tastes the Paella; disgusted) Again         with the pepper? What do you gotta use all the pepper for?
Ah keep quiet.
What are you trying to set my mouth on fire?
I don't know what the reason could be.
(disappointed) Oh, Hi, hi.
Ah Jerry you would not believe the time we had.
Aaron is quite the tour guide.
Jerry have you ever seen any of those impressionist paintings?
Oh sure like Monet.
Don't you think he had to be uh near sighted? I mean nobody would         paint like that if they could see. It's all out of focus.
Well he's from the impressionist school, you know like Monet,         Manet, Tippi Tippi Dayday.
I say the guy was painting without his glasses.
(answering phone) Hello? Rachel, ya uh no they're back.
Jerry if you have something to do we could just sit right here         and read.
Uh haha ya well uh I'm sorry too I'll call you later, ok bye (hangs         phone up)
Well I should be going.
Oh thanks again.
Buh bye.
Oh you must be Kramer (advances on Kramer to close to his face         Kramer walks back into the fridge to avoid him and falls to the ground)         I've heard about you.
You must be Aaron, I've heard about you.
(Laughing) Well see you later.
Yeah.
(leaving) Bye

We have no plans.

The belt-less trench coat. My father invented it.
I sure did. Raincoats were my business. The Executive was a classic,         these haven't been made in twenty years.

He's wearing one.
Yea these are a hot item over at Rudy's.
You don't say? You know I have boxes of those sitting in my garage         in Florida?
Get 'em up here. You give me twenty-five percent I-I'll take         care of everything.
You gotta deal.
Yaaaa.
This is like the meeting of Smith and Wesson.

You're crazy.
I'll tell you how crazy I am, I'm gonna pay for this whole trip         with these coats.
N-na I'm paying for the trip.

Anyway it's kind of a fluke thing but uh I'll be leaving for         Paris in two days. I will send you a postcard when I get there.
Paris huh?
Yea, ya..ya know I feel terrible about Joey but it's jus..it's         a great business opportunity. I-I don't even know how long I'm gonna be         away for.
Where will you stay?
An apartment complex, the uh the Eiffel Towers. uumm Like I said         uh you'll be getting a postcard uh in a few days and again I'm sorry.
George, you have no idea how fantastic this is.
Fantastic?

Ya, we've been trying to reunite Joey with his father who lives         in Paris. But he's afraid to fly alone, you know he's kinda withdrawn,         but he seems to take to you. (George smiling in surprise) So it's a perfect         solution.
How gee what a coincidence.
And you'll send me a postcard.

Aaron

I came home one night, and I tripped over one of Jerry's toys.         (Jerry smiling points to himself and nods with cards in his hands) So         I took out my belt just to threaten him, and I got a glimpse of myself         in the mirror.

So that night I cut off the loops and the Executive was born.
Mmm

I haven't been able to reach him. Hey I'll call him right now.

Raincoats.

Not for another three days.
What about her place?
She lives with her parents.
Really? (Jerry shakes his head) Maybe this will become like a         cool thing, living with your parents.
(sarcastically)Ya, then maybe baldness will catch on. This will         all be turning your way.
Hey believe me, baldness will catch on. When the aliens come,         who do you think they're gonna relate to? Who do you think is going to         be the first ones getting a tour of the ship?
The baldies
Hey by the way my parents really want to have your parents over         dinner before they leave town.
That's good, then I get the apartment for at least one night.         You know I'm paying for this whole Paris trip it's their anniversary present.
(walking over to Jerry and George's table) Hey guys.
Hey Alec
Hey Alec
This is Joey.
Hey Joey, how you doin'?

(Joey was about to talk) Hey listen, I was wondering if either         one of you guys would be interested in doing some work for the Big Brother         program? I'm kinda running the local chapter. What do you say George?
Well uh....
(interrupts) Wouldn't you like to be a big brother to someone like         me? Please?
Well, sure Joey, sure, I would be thrilled.
That's great George, thanks a lot I'll get in touch with you.
Wouldn't you like to be a big brother..
(grabs Joey to stop him) Ya alright Joey that's enough, let's go         (walking over to the counter) See ya.
What happened?
What could I do? Did you see the mug on that kid?
(acting like Joey) Wouldn't you like to pass the ketchup to someone         like me? Please?
Hey did you notice they moved where they do the interview on Jeopardy         now?
Ya it used to be right in the middle of single Jeopardy and now         they do it right after single Jeopardy.
Ya, it's much better isn't it?
Oh, n-no comparison.
Hey, I gotta stop off at the bookstore to pick up my parents one         of those French-English dictionaries.
(stops Jerry realizing something) Hey hey hey hey hey hey.
What?
Your parents are going to Paris right?
Yea?
So I tell Alec that I have to goto Paris for an undetermined         amount of time. Then all I have to do is buy some post cards and have         your parents mail them from Paris.
What about little Joey?
Who?
Ah, I think he's probably better off.
I'm trying to get out of this Big Brother program. So when you         get to Paris (handing Morty the postcards) all you have to do is drop         'em in any mailbox.
But there are no stamps on these.
Well no not yet, you gotta buy french stamps (pauses) I-I'll         reimburse you of course.
Why are you doing this?
He wants this guy to think he's in Paris.
Why?
Because George is a deeply disturbed individual.
Oh hey, Helen uh, Could I uh, use some more of your hand lotion?
I told you it was good. (hands Kramer the lotion)
(putting on the lotion) Ya
It's from the Sachs Fifth Avenue in Miami.
Mmm (smelling the lotion as he rubs it in) I'm gonna remember         that if I'm ever in Florida.
Ya, or if you're ever on Fifth Avenue here in New York City, you         could get some there.
Ya
Say those are some nice pants. I got a pair just like them at         home.

Well uh that doesn't surprise me, ya i bought these at Rudy's.         It's a used clothing store. See when people like you die, the widows they         bring in their wardrobes, they make a bundle.
Really? My father has a ton of old clothes just sitting up in         the attic, y-you think they're worth something?
Ya if they're vintage, and you're a widow.
What happens if the husband dies after the wife, who brings in         the clothing in then?
Well I suppose the children do.
(pondering) Yes I suppose they do.
(takes another smell of his hands) Alright I gotta a ten o'clock,         I'll see everybody later.
(grabbing his jacket) Hey oo, I just remembered uh my parents         really wanna have you guys over for dinner before you leave town. What         about tonight?
Tonight?
Yea they're making Payaya.
(looking at Morty) Uh oh I don't think we think we can make it         tonight, (turns toward George) we have plans.
(watching the whole conversation from his desk) What plans?
(turns to Jerry) We have plans.
Where'd you get plans?
(annoyed) We have plans.
Well um, what about tomorrow night?
(turns back toward George) Maybe
Ok uh, I guess I'll tell them that.
(to George as he is about to leave) Hey give 'em our best though.
(quietly) Ya.
(walking over toward George and the door) I'll call you later.
Ya.
So what plans do you have?
None
So how come you're not going over there for dinner?
Jerry we don't care much for the Costanzas'.
We can't stand them.
Really? Since when?
Since always. We've never liked them.
Why?
Well they're so loud, they're always fighting it's uncomfortable,         you never notice?
No I notice but they're from your age group I didn't know you         could detect abnormal behavior among your own kind.
Well we do.
Ya?
It's us.
U-oh come on up. (buzzes them up) It's Elaine you don't have a         problem with her do you?
We adore Elaine.
She wants to say hi, she's with her new boyfriend.
What's he like?
He's nice, bit of a close talker.
A what?
You'll see. (pause) Boy, I had no idea you felt this way about         the Costanzas'
They're exhausting it's like being in an Asylum.
Hi.
Hello Elaine
This is Aaron.
Hello Aaron
Hello.
(getting up in Helen's face) So how long you folks in town?
Oh, three more days, three more days then we're off to Paris.
Ah
We're going with a select charter group.
I love France, (moving over to Morty's face) I was just there         last year. In fact, you know I still have an envelope full of French Franks,         I'll give 'em to ya.
We can't take money.
Oh, no, it's a gift. (looking toward Elaine) from us.
Oh, that is soo nice (very elaborate nice) Aaron. Isn't he nice?         (to Helen) So listen has Jerry been showin' you a good time?
No I haven't.
You know (to Morty) I have a friend who works at the Metropolitan         Museum of Art. How would you like a behind the scenes tour?
(grabbing Aaron) Really, you could do that?
(up in Helen's face) Easily
I wouldn't be any trouble?
(gets closer) Of course not.
When would we go?
How about right now?
I'm ready
Are you sure?
Yes.
Ok, let me get my coat.
(walking over to Elaine and getting into her face) Elaine what         do you say?
W-well I don't think so Aaron, uh, I have plans.
Oh. (getting into Jerry's face) How about you Jerry?
I'm swamped.
You sure? You could examine the art work up close.
Maybe I'll try and catch up with you.
(under her breath) Ya that'll happen)
(Moving toward the door) Alright. We're off.
Ok, bye.
Bye.
Ok buh bye. Have a good time.
Bye.
See everybody later (Morty and Helen leave; Aaron closes the door         blowing Elaine a kiss)
Ok.
Why would he ask your parents to go to a museum?
I don't know.
What is that?
Maybe he was just trying to be nice.
Have you ever heard of anyone doing anything like this?
Wait a second, he just did me a big favor.
What?
(dialing) He got em out of the house.
What?
Call Rachel.
Oh.
(on the phone) ah no, I got the machine. Rachel! Are you there?!         I got the place to myself for a few hours! Rachel! Where are you? Rachel!         (hangs up the phone very disappointed)
(putting on lipstick) Sorry pal, wish I could help you out.
They're not coming?
No, they had plans.
How could they have plans?
That's what I wanna know.
Well what difference does it make? They wouldn't lie to us, they're         are dear friends.
What am I supposed to do with all this Paella?
They said tomorrow, maybe.
Maybe?
Maybe they don't like us.
Why wouldn't they like us? (tastes the Paella; disgusted) Again         with the pepper? What do you gotta use all the pepper for?
Ah keep quiet.
What are you trying to set my mouth on fire?
I don't know what the reason could be.
(disappointed) Oh, Hi, hi.
Ah Jerry you would not believe the time we had.
Aaron is quite the tour guide.
Jerry have you ever seen any of those impressionist paintings?
Oh sure like Monet.
Don't you think he had to be uh near sighted? I mean nobody would         paint like that if they could see. It's all out of focus.
Well he's from the impressionist school, you know like Monet,         Manet, Tippi Tippi Dayday.
I say the guy was painting without his glasses.
(answering phone) Hello? Rachel, ya uh no they're back.
Jerry if you have something to do we could just sit right here         and read.
Uh haha ya well uh I'm sorry too I'll call you later, ok bye (hangs         phone up)
Well I should be going.
Oh thanks again.
Buh bye.
Oh you must be Kramer (advances on Kramer to close to his face         Kramer walks back into the fridge to avoid him and falls to the ground)         I've heard about you.
You must be Aaron, I've heard about you.
(Laughing) Well see you later.
Yeah.
(leaving) Bye
Bye
So uh what are you guys doing for dinner?
We have no plans.
(noticing Kramer's coat) Look at that, Helen do you see what he's         wearing? That's the Executive.
Now what is Executive?
The belt-less trench coat. My father invented it.
I sure did. Raincoats were my business. The Executive was a classic,         these haven't been made in twenty years.
Why would they? Nobody bought them then.
He's wearing one.
Yea these are a hot item over at Rudy's.
You don't say? You know I have boxes of those sitting in my garage         in Florida?
Get 'em up here. You give me twenty-five percent I-I'll take         care of everything.
You gotta deal.
Yaaaa.
This is like the meeting of Smith and Wesson.
I'll call Jack Klompus, he's got a key to the garage. He can send         them overnight delivery.
You're gonna first start shipping boxes? We're leaving for Paris         in three days.
He'll send them express.
You're crazy.
I'll tell you how crazy I am, I'm gonna pay for this whole trip         with these coats.
N-na I'm paying for the trip.
So much the better.
Anyway it's kind of a fluke thing but uh I'll be leaving for         Paris in two days. I will send you a postcard when I get there.
Paris huh?
Yea, ya..ya know I feel terrible about Joey but it's jus..it's         a great business opportunity. I-I don't even know how long I'm gonna be         away for.
Where will you stay?
An apartment complex, the uh the Eiffel Towers. uumm Like I said         uh you'll be getting a postcard uh in a few days and again I'm sorry.
George, you have no idea how fantastic this is.
Fantastic?

Ya, we've been trying to reunite Joey with his father who lives         in Paris. But he's afraid to fly alone, you know he's kinda withdrawn,         but he seems to take to you. (George smiling in surprise) So it's a perfect         solution.
How gee what a coincidence.
And you'll send me a postcard.
Helen really seemed to respond to Renoir. I think she really connected         to the way he painted children.
Mm hmm.
And that Morty, I'll tell ya that guy is full of life. (laughs)         He was convinced Monet was near sighted. I kept telling him
Aaron
Yes?
Uh, let me ask you a question. How come you asked Mr. and Mrs.         Seinfeld to go to the museum with you?
Well, they were in from out of town, I thought they would enjoy         it.
Uhuh, um you didn't feel uncomfortable spending the whole day         at the museum with two complete strangers who were more than twice your         age?
No, it was fun.
You had fun with Mr. and Mrs. Seinfeld.
Yea, they bought me a coke.
So how'd you come up with the idea for the belt-less trench coat?

I came home one night, and I tripped over one of Jerry's toys.         (Jerry smiling points to himself and nods with cards in his hands) So         I took out my belt just to threaten him, and I got a glimpse of myself         in the mirror.
How serendipitous.
So that night I cut off the loops and the Executive was born.
Mmm
He also came up with an idea for a brimless rain-hat but that         never materialized. (to Morty) Alright come on let's play.
Did you call Jack Klompus yet?
I haven't been able to reach him. Hey I'll call him right now.
Ah come on.
Just a second. (Goes to grab the phone)
Jerry have you seen Schindler's List?
No I haven't seen it yet.
Oh you have to go you have to
I'm going
You have to
Ok
(on the phone) Hello Jack.
Ya
It's Morty
Who died?
Nobody died. Jack I want you to do me a big favor. (Jerry holding         up some cards looking at his father) In my garage there are a couple of         boxes.
What boxes?
I'm gonna explain what boxes.
Alright how the hell do I know?
Anyway there are these three big boxes, you can't miss them. I         want you to ship them here to New York for me.
I thought you're going to Paris
I'm still going to Paris. I got a big deal cooking here.
What's in the boxes?
Raincoats.
Raincoats? (Doris sighs) You think you're gonna sell those old         crappy raincoats? That's garbage.
I guarantee you Doris is not letting him mail those boxes.
When do you want these?
Send them tomorrow.
You think they're coming tonight?
I dunno they said maybe.
Of course they're coming, they're leaving soon. If they don't         come tonight they might not see us.
Well they better come, I got all this Paella.
I admire Morty and Helen going to France. We should take a trip,         maybe a cruise.
Yes a cruise, a long cruise, just the two of you.
Georgie what were you doing poking around the attic last night?
I-I wasn't in the attic.
I heard noise.
Maybe it was a mouse.
(jumping to his feet) OK that's it! We're moving!
What?
I will not tolerate infestation.
You haven't even seen one.
Don't you understand the very thought, the very idea, I'll never         be comfortable again.

character: Directed by Tom Cherones. Written by Larry Charles.        Guest stars
line: Melanie Chartoff (Robin)        Veanne Cox (Toby)        Dom Irrera (Ronnie)        Jon Favreau (Eric the Clown)        Lisa Pescia (Joanne)        Hiram Kasten (Michael)        Patience Cleveland (Robin's mother)        Lawrence LeJohn (Fireman)        Jerry Stiller (Frank Costanza, voice only)        Estelle Harris (Estelle Costanza, voice only)

To me, the thing about birthday parties is that         the first birthday party you have and the last birthday party you have         are actually quite similar. You know, you just kinda sit there...you're         the least excited person at the party. You don't even really realize that         there is a party. You don't know what's goin' on. Both birthday parties,         people have to kinda help you blow out the candles, you can't do it...you         don't even know why you're doing it. What is this ritual? What is going         on? It's also the only two birthday parties where other people have to         gather your friends together for you. Sometimes they're not even         your friends. They make the judgement. They bring 'em in, they sit 'em         down, and they tell you - 'these are your friends! Tell them thank you         for coming to my birthday party.'
These are great! Just great! Really great! Really,         really great! Don't you think so, Elaine?
Yeah, really great.
A coffee table book about coffee tables! <To Kramer> How         did you come up with this idea?
It was there!
Oh, look at this one! It's saying, 'I'm a coffee table, put some         coffee on me! Oh, the hotter the better, that's what I'm here for!' <laughs>
Actually, I've got some work I gotta do, so...
Hey, how about if the book came with these little fold-out legs...so         the book itself becomes a coffee table?
Ohhh, that is a great idea! Really, really great!

'And that coffee table is saying, put some coffee         on me!' I'd like to put some coffee on her. Hot, scalding coffee - right         in her face! I swear! This is like working with a contestant from "The         Price Is Right"! <demonstrates>

Yeah, that's real interesting. Elaine, listen, tell me if you         think this is funny - <reads comedy he's written> "Men definitely         hit the remote more than women...men don't care what's on TV, men only         care what else is on TV. Women want to see what the show is before         they change the channel, because men hunt and women nest."
Yeah, it's funny, I dunno.
You don't know? Come on, that's gold!
Well, I don't know about "gold."
Oh, that's gold, baby.
'Baby'? What, are you doing George now?
I was saying 'baby' way before George!
Well, I don't know, don't ask me any more questions about jokes,         Jerry, it puts too much pressure on me.
Well, this guy Leonard Christian's gonna be there tomorrow night.
Yeah, who's he?
He's a writer from Entertainment Weekly. I would like to         have a good show.
Danke schoen, my little dumplings.
Hi.
Hey, how about that Toby, huh?
Yeah, how about her?
Ooh, she's a package full of energy!
Yeah, she's a package full of something.
And that something is life. Jerry, you gotta meet this gal -         she's brimmin' with positivity!
Oh, pleeeeease. <moves to the living         room and sits down>
Hey, are you performing tomorrow night?
Yeah.
Great, I'm gonna bring Toby.
Well, you better laugh 'cause I'm being reviewed. Leonard Christian's         gonna be there.
Oh, she's a great laugher - right, Elaine?
Oh yeah, she's a great laugher, Jerry. <imitates Toby>         Really, really great!
Well, you want to sit with George? I think he's coming         with Robin.
Is that the waitress from the comedy club?
Yeah.
What about her kid, is she bringing him, too?
She's got a kid?
Yeah, you should see George get along with this kid!
Ow! What are you doing under there? Hey, stop that! Don't eat         that! That's not food! <to Robin> He's suckin' down Equal packets!
Do you think 25 kids is too much?
25 kids for his birthday party? <to kid under table> Don't         put your tongue on the floor! He's putting his tongue on the floor! Here,         here, have some more sugar packets.
So, what about entertainment? <to kid> Should I get Barney?
No Barney!
Maybe a clown.
How about Bozo?
Who's Bozo?
Who's Bozo? Bozo the Clown, that's who Bozo is. When I was a         kid, Bozo the Clown was the clown, bar none.
George...
With the orange hair, and the big clown shirt with the ruffles...
George...
And the TV show! He had cartoons!
George! Forget Bozo, George. Bozo's out. He's finished. It's over         for Bozo.
You know, when I was a kid, we didn't have these elaborate birthday         parties with catered food and entertainment. I remember my 7th birthday         party...

character: We see a flashback of George at seven, sitting in front of a birthday         cake with a shocked expression on his face, while Frank and Estelle scream         at him

line: Blow out the candles! Blow out the candles, I said! Blow out         the damn candles!
Stop it, Frank! You're killing him!
Well, this time, you can blow out the candles.
Nah, I have asthma. <Robin's kid grabs George's leg from under         the table, and George struggles.>
Hi!
Hi, Toby.
How are you doing today?
Fine... <Toby sits and waits for Elaine to speak.> How         are you?
Oh, I'm great! Just great. Really great! Oh, hey - did you hear         about Bob Rosen?
Nope.
He is going to Knopp. He is going to be a vice president.
Knopp? Really? Boy. That means there's an opening here for senior         editor...has Lippman, uh, hired anyone?
No. I hear he wants to promote someone in-house.
Really!
Maybe it'll be you!
Oh...well...
You really deserve it. I mean, you have experience, seniority...Lippman         really respects your opinion...
Well! Well, it could be you.
No...
No, really.
Really? You think so?
Sure.
Boy, wouldn't that be exciting!
I mean, stranger things have happened...
Wow! Me! A senior editor! <deadly serious> I'd like that.
Well, you shouldn't get your hopes up, Toby.
Well, it's a possibility, like you said! Stranger things have happened!         Thank you, Elaine. Thank you. <Exits.>
Hey, Ronnie. <To bartender> Can I have a club soda? <To         Ronnie> Goin' on tonight?
Yeah. You?
Yeah.
You know Leonard Christian's here?
Yeah, I know.
Can I ask you something? Are my nostrils getting bigger?
I don't...think so.
Are you sure? Take a good look. They seem a little bigger?
I don't...I dunno.
Is it possible for nostrils to expand?
Oh, is this a bit?
Hey, I don't do "bits." I'm a prop comic. Dammit, I         can't find my water gun. I can't go on without my water gun.
Hey, Jerry. Toby, this is Jerry.
This is so exciting! Look, I have goosebumps! <To Jerry>         Touch! Touch them! <Jerry touches her arm. Toby screeches with excitement.>         I've never been to a comedy club before!
Really! You know, a lot of restaurants are serving brewed decaf         now, too.
You are so funny!
Oh, you'll have a good time, I swear.
Oh! He swears like he thinks I don't believe him. I believe you.         I believe you! Oh, he's so funny! <laughs>
What about me?
What about you? <laughs> I'm only kidding. You're         funny, too. I love to laugh.
Good, good.
So, you up next?
Yeah, why don't you guys get a table so you'll have good seats?

Oh yeah, we don't want some jerk sitting in front of us, it'll         be like, 'Hey, big head, can you move out of the way? I didn't pay a cover         charge to stare at your bald spot.' <laughs>
Alright, so you have a good show, huh buddy?
Yeah.
Oh, have a great show. Hey, we'll make sure it's a great show!
O.k., good, I'll see you later. <Kramer and Toby are about         to exit. She turns around and clutches Kramer's jacket.>
Oh, he's so great! This is so great! I'm so excited!
Men definitely hit the remote button more than women...
Oh, really! Really! That is so true!
Yes, yeah...see, men don't care what's on TV, men only care what         else is on TV.
Yes! Yes! Right on! Right on! <Other audience members give her         puzzled looks.>

character: JERRY (attempting to carry on despite Toby's interruptions)
line: See...women         really want to see what the show is before they change the channel...
Oh, that is so true, yes!
...that's why men hunt and women nest.
BOO! BOO! Hiss! Boo! <Toby's obnoxious behavior causes Jerry         to completely lose his place and mess up his act.>
Hey, what's the deal? What was goin' on there? I invite you down         here, I have an important show, and she heckles me?!
Look, she didn't mean anything.
Well, what is the matter with her? Is she crazy?!
She's just being enthusiastic, that's all!
Hey! What is wrong with you?!
Me? Nothing's wrong with me.
You boo me?! You hiss?! You didn't stop blathering throughout         the whole set!
Oh, come on! I thought you're a pro! That's part of the show.
No! Not part of the show! Booing and hissing are not part of the         show! You boo puppets! You hiss villains in silent movies!
Well, that's the way I express myself. How are you gonna make it         in this business if you can't take it?
Oh, I can take it.
Let's go. <Ronnie walks by Jerry.>
Hey, man. Good set.
Bozo?
No.
B-O-Z-O?
Sorry, I...
You've never heard of Bozo the Clown?
No!
How could you not know who Bozo the Clown is?
I don't know, I just don't.
How can you call yourself a clown and not know who Bozo is?
Hey, man - what are you hassling me for? This is just a gig, it's         not my life. I don't know who Bozo is, what - is he a clown?
Is he a clown? What, are you kidding me!?
Well, what is he?
Yes, he's a clown!
Alright, so what's the big deal! There's millions of clowns!
Alright, just forget it.
Me forget it? You should forget it! You're livin' in the past,         man! You're hung up on some clown from the sixties, man!
Alright, very good, very good...go fold your little balloon animals,         Eric. Eric! What kind of name is that for a clown, huh?
Excuse me...you must be George! I'm Robin's mother. Oh,         you seem like such a lovely young man!
Well, I do what I can. <Robin comes over.>
Hi Mom, how's everything?
Oh, this is just a wonderful party!
The burgers should be ready in a minute.

Ah, great, great. <sniffs> What's that smell? Smoke? <walks         to the kitchen> Hey everybody, I think I smell some smoke back here...<smoke         boils into the doorway.> FIRE! FIRE! Get out of the way!
It was an inferno in there! An inferno! <Eric,         Robin's mother, and all the kids rush at George.>
There he is! That's him! <Tries to clobber George with his big         shoe.>
That's the coward that left us to die!
I...was trying to lead the way.         We needed a leader! Someone to lead the way to safety.
But you yelled "get out of my way"!

Because! Because, as the leader...if I die...then all hope is         lost! Who would lead? The clown? Instead of castigating me, you should         all be thanking me. What kind of a topsy-turvy world do we live in, where         heroes are cast as villains? Brave men as cowards?
But I saw you push the women and children out of the way in a         mad panic! I saw you knock them down! And when you ran out, you left everyone         behind!

Seemingly. Seemingly, to the untrained eye, I can fully understand         how you got that impression. What looked like pushing...what looked like         knocking down...was a safety precaution! In a fire, you stay close to         the ground, am I right? And when I ran out that door, I was not leaving         anyone behind! Oh, quite the contrary! I risked my life making sure that         exit was clear. Any other questions?
How do you live with yourself?
Its not easy.
So she doesn't want to see me anymore.
Did you knock her over too, or just the kids?
No, her too. And her mother.
Really? Her mother.
Yeah. I may have stepped on her arm, too, I don't know.
You probably couldn't see because of the smoke.
Yeah. But it was somebody's arm.
So you feel "women and children first," in this day         and age, is somewhat of an antiquated notion.
To some degree.
So basically, it's every man, woman, child, and invalid for themselves.
In a manner of speaking.
Well, it's honest.
Yeah. She should be commending me for treating everyone like         equals.
Well, perhaps when she's released from the burn center, she'll         see things differently.
Perhaps.
So, what was the fire? Just a couple of greasy hamburgers?
Yeah. Eric the Clown put it out with his big shoe.
By the way, did you see this? <Hands George a magazine>
What's that?
It's the Leonard Christian article about my show. Plus my gig         in Miami got cancelled, I betcha it's because of the article.
Wow, he really does a number on you. <reads> "Seinfeld         froze like a deer in the headlights in the face of incessant heckling."
I should have let her have it! I held back because of Kramer.
You know what you oughta do. You should go to her office and         heckle her.
Yeah, right.
You know, like all the comedians always say, 'How would you like         it if I came to where you work and heckled you?'
Yeah, that'd be something.
I'm not kidding, you should do it.
But wouldn't that be the ultimate comedian's revenge? I've always         had a fantasy about doing that.
Well, go ahead! Do it!
Why can't I?
No reason!
You know what? I think I'm gonna do that! She came down to where         I work, I'll go down to where she works!
This is unprecedented!
